This course is the foundation upon which your MBA studies will be built. It is in this period that you and your cohort will develop a shared understanding of what it means to be an AGSM graduate - what leadership characteristics you will foster; what values you will adhere to; and what behaviours you believe will assist lifelong learning and leadership. Importantly, you will be asked to reflect on how you wish to approach the MBA experience and you will have the opportunity to set your own goals.


The premises of the first section of the course which is entitled Leading Yourself and Others (LYO) is that:


  • leading yourself effectively is a prerequisite for being at your best and bringing out the best in others
  • learning to lead well requires continual openness to challenging your assumptions and experimenting with fresh ways to attain your objectives.

LYO has been designed to enable you to be in learning mode (Heslin & Keating 2017) regarding how you lead yourself to thrive in your MBA Program and develop your capacity to forge a successful career as you make a positive impact on individuals, organisations, and the communities in which you work.

During the CAL experiential workshop keep a journal each day where you:

1. reflect on the prorogress you made during the course as well as the concepts, models, frameworks, and leadership traits and styles that you can incorporate into your own leadership style. 

2. Provide a summary of at least one piece of 'vicarious modelling'. Defined as an example of outstanding leadership traits that you witnessed from other course members during the experiential phase.

contentlets.description:
This course is the foundation upon which your MBA studies will be built. It is in this period that you and your cohort will develop a shared understanding of what it means to be an AGSM graduate - what leadership characteristics you will foster; what values you will adhere to; and what behaviours you believe will assist lifelong learning and leadership. Importantly, you will be asked to reflect on how you wish to approach the MBA experience and you will have the opportunity to set your own goals.

The premises of the first section of the course which is entitled Leading Yourself and Others (LYO) is that:

  • leading yourself effectively is a prerequisite for being at your best and bringing out the best in others
  • learning to lead well requires continual openness to challenging your assumptions and experimenting with fresh ways to attain your objectives.

LYO has been designed to enable you to be in learning mode (Heslin & Keating 2017) regarding how you lead yourself to thrive in your MBA Program and develop your capacity to forge a successful career as you make a positive impact on individuals, organisations, and the communities in which you work.

Operationalising Strategy","description":"

This course covers the design and redesign of organisations and work. The focus of this course is on the general concepts and enduring principles that underlie the process and practice of redesign. Many of these concepts and principles will be illustrated by our analysis of case studies.


Our aim is not to give a cookbook of all possible new technologies or management techniques with detailed prescriptions about their implementation. Such a cookbook would quickly outlive its usefulness. Rather, this course is concerned with enduring design concepts and principles that transcend particular types of ‘buzz’ initiatives or management fads. These concepts and principles can be applied to all sorts of redesigns, not just those currently ‘in vogue’. We consider not just how to design the organisation to deliver on the organisation’s strategy, but also how best to implement new organisation designs. We consider how team and individual work can be designed to align with the organisation design. Finally we review examples of particular initiatives that have significant implications for strategic redesign including mergers and acquisitions, outsourcing and downsizing.

Economics in Management Practice","description":"

The performance of an organisation is driven by firm-specific, industry and economic factors. Economics in Management Practice has been developed to give you a deeper understanding of all three of these factors and to provide a rigourous foundation for any further study that you pursue in the area of Strategy.


Microeconomics is the focus of Units 1 to 6 of this course. It provides you with a deeper understanding of both firm-specific and industry factors that drive financial performance. These Units cover the purchase decisions of individual customers and how the features of the industry will influence company profitability. An understanding of microeconomics helps managers to better understand and predict the behaviour of customers, competitors and suppliers. These concepts are foundational to any further study in the area of strategy.


Macroeconomics is the focus of Units 7 to 11 of this course. It provides you with a deeper understanding of the economic factors that drive financial performance. These Units cover that factors that drive economic growth, inflation, employment, interest rates and exchange rates. An understanding of macroeconomics helps managers to better understand and predict how changes in the economy will affect the industry in which they operate.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"e973ad7fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a96198b","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 2: Quizzes","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"10","description":"

This assessment includes a series of weekly online quizzes on the course website that you can perform in the comfort of your own home. There are 10 quizzes in total based on Units 2 to 11 and they are due in Weeks 2 to 11. Each quiz will consist of just 5 questions. Most questions are multiple-choice style but there are also a few calculation questions. You will have 1 hour to complete each quiz from the time you first open it. Your final grade will be based on your best 8 quiz scores. For more detailed information about this assessment including the start and finish times for each quiz, please refer to the 'Quiz Instructions' document under the 'Quizzes' section of the course website.

Active participation and interaction with your peers is an important part of this course. If you are enrolled in a face-to-face weekly or intensive class, your participation will be scored based on your attendance and interactions in class. If you are enrolled in a web class, it will be scored based on your interaction in the discussion forums. In order to receive a participation mark, you must upload a clear photograph of yourself onto your profile on Moodle by the end of Week 3 of session. For more detailed information about this assessment, please refer to the 'Participation Instructions' document under the 'Participtation' section of the course website.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"1173ad7fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961961","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"5d73ad7fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961963","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"9573ad7fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a96195b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"a173ad7fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961985","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"a973ad7fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961966","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"d173ad7fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a96195e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO8","cl_id":"ed73ad7fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961987","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"8573ad7fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a96191a","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 3A: Assignment","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

The Assignment (30%) and Presentation (10%) involves choosing a real case based on your industry experience, describing that case and then analysing it using the principles covered in Units 1 to 6 of the course. The assessment includes three components: Proposal (due Week 6), Assignment (due Week 10) and a Presentation (due Week 11). The Proposal involves preparing a brief document outlining your group members, your chosen topic and your project plan. The Assignment involves preparing a written case study and solution. The Presentation involves recording a presentation explaining the case study and solution using Microsoft PowerPoint. Each group member must present part of the presentation and you will be marked individually. You will have access to assignments and presentations from previous sessions to help you with this assessment. For more detailed information about this assessment, please refer to the 'Assignment Instructions' and 'Presentation Instructions' documents under the 'Assignment' and 'Presentation' section of the course website.

The final assessment is a take-home exam that you can perform in the comfort of your own home. It will involve using the macroeconomic models covered in Units 7 to 11 of the course to analyse a particular country's economy over a selected period of time. You will receive the exam question to your student email address by the 'Start date' listed above. You must submit your written report on the course website by the 'Due date' listed above. For more detailed information about this assessment, please refer to the 'Exam Instructions' document under the 'Exam' section of the course website.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"MNGT5202","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"MNGT5202 - Entrepreneurship and Innovation","description":"

This course suits individuals looking to build their strategic abilities around entrepreneurship and corporate innovation. It provides exposure to both the fundamentals of business innovation and the practical aspects of identifying, evaluating and moving business ideas forward. The course uniquely links current students with innovators, venture capital (VC) groups, and successful start-up CEOs.


This dynamic course pulls together many of the components already learned in the MBA Program, providing those with entrepreneurial aspirations the opportunity to realise their dreams.


Two streams of entrepreneurship are covered in the course: start-up creation and corporate innovation. Three specific methodologies of corporate innovation will be covered: Design Thinking, Open Innovation and The Lean Start-up.

Complete a 30-question multiple-choice online quiz during class. Students will have 60 minutes to complete this assessment.

All subject matter from Weeks 1 to 4 (including guest presentations) is assessable.

Create and deliver a team presentation which describes the business model being built (Option A) or the innovation business model being investigated (Option B).

Teams will be provided with the presentation format in Week 2.

Each team will be limited to five minutes of presentation time and then 5 minutes of Q&A. Each team member will be assessed individually for their contribution.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO10","cl_id":"02d36dbfdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619c6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"0ad36dbfdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619ab","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"35d36dbfdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619a0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO11","cl_id":"5ed36dbfdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619c8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"71d36dbfdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619a3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"82d36dbfdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619b1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO12","cl_id":"9ad36dbfdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619cb","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO8","cl_id":"ced36dbfdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619b3","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"6dd36dbfdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961974","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 3: Take-home Case Study","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"25","description":"

Students will be randomly assigned to two-person teams. Each team will have 24 hours to answer questions relating to a case study.

This is a take-home case. It is available from 11pm on Friday 9 August and is due for submission by 11pm on Saturday 10 August 2019 Sydney time

Submission only needs to be made by one member of the pair. 

Each team member will be assessed individually for their contribution.

Collusion between pairs will result in failure.

Two streams of entrepreneurship are covered in the course: start-up creation and corporate innovation. Three specific methodologies of corporate innovation will be covered: Design Thinking, Open Innovation and The Lean Start-up.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"MNGT5203 - Entrepreneurship from the Inside","description":"

The emphasis in this course will be 'the experience'. It is designed to be experiential rather than lecture-theatre based.


You will be placed as an Intern in a startup around Sydney. You will be part of that startup team, working on a strategic project that will be of significant value to the startup. It is an excellent immersive experience! Very rarely, if at all, does someone get the opportunity to work in a startup environment. The expectation is that you would spend, on average, a day a week in the startup. You will use the material you have learned in the core course, together with bringing to bear your experience prior to the MBA, plus the experiences you have already had. 


Overall, the aim of the course is to provide you with a significant 'immersive' and 'experiential' experience as an entrepreneur in real life. It is very rare that you would experience this anywhere else.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"e805513bdbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619ba","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 3: Final Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"5","weighting":"30","description":"

Write a detailed report about the project you have been working on, and the impact that it has made.

contentlets.description:
The emphasis in this course will be 'the experience'. It is designed to be experiential rather than lecture-theatre based.

You will be placed as an Intern in a startup around Sydney. You will be part of that startup team, working on a strategic project that will be of significant value to the startup. It is an excellent immersive experience! Very rarely, if at all, does someone get the opportunity to work in a startup environment. The expectation is that you would spend, on average, a day a week in the startup. You will use the material you have learned in the core course, together with bringing to bear your experience prior to the MBA, plus the experiences you have already had. 

Overall, the aim of the course is to provide you with a significant 'immersive' and 'experiential' experience as an entrepreneur in real life. It is very rare that you would experience this anywhere else.
contentlets.title: Entrepreneurship from the Inside

Accounting and Financial Management","description":"

The course provides a broad introduction to all aspects of the accounting function. The language of accounting and financial management is exacting. Our aim is to increase your familiarity with key components of this language and allow you to more effectively communicate with all organisational stakeholders. Given the users of accounting information may be typically classified as either external users (such as investors) or internal users (such as operational managers). Different users have different information needs. This course deals with the needs of these two main user groups and how the senior management of organisations can more effectively use accounting data to connect with them.


The subject will explore accounting techniques and terminology, to equip participants with sufficient conceptual and practical skills to make them, and any professional who may advise them, confident in their ability to understand and communicate complex financial strategies.


This subject also examines the design and operation of accounting systems. As a result, the course integrates ideas and concepts from accounting with a range of other disciplines and reveals how the effective use of financial information provided by such systems can improve organisational decision-making.


It is assumed that participants have little prior knowledge of accounting and financial management.

contentlets.description: Provides an introduction to the three basic ideas in finance: the time value of money, diversification and arbitrage. These ideas are used to evaluate investment and financing decisions. In particular, we look at how managers can apply these concepts to add value to the firm.
contentlets.title: Corporate Finance

Data Analysis and Statistical Modelling for Business","description":"

In recent years, organisations have aligned technology and business in order to adapt to a challenging and hyper-competitive market environment. In a situation where organisations in many industries offer similar products and use equivalent technologies, business processes are established as one of the last points of differentiation. In a similar way, data and algorithms have become the new stronghold upon which to leverage differentiation processes, products, services and decision-making. As a result, increasingly more companies use different analytical strategies to improve decision-making, optimise processes and create data-driven products.


However, as in many other areas, technology is not sufficient to generate competitive advantage status. For example, decision-making requires actual art (based on experience and intuition) and science (based on analysis) to survive the increasing complexity of the market. Understanding how to use data, models, visuals and dashboards to create competitive advantages can be the key to the success or failure of a company in the coming years.


This course aims to introduce professionals to Data Analytics and how to develop efficient strategies within organisations. The efficiency is achieved through the combination of multiple technologies (from Business Intelligence to Big Data) and the use of algorithms to generate insights and predict the future behaviour of an organisation.


This course introduces managers to several techniques that are relevant for managerial decision-making, such as data preparation, data analysis, data visualisation and data storytelling.


This course will help students to develop expertise in a standard set of data literature techniques, which will be useful in analysing business-related data. These techniques are widely applied in a number of areas of management, including operations, marketing, finance, and human resources.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"26dde14fdbc35450358b403c3a961963","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Assessment 2: Strategic Decision Making Simulation - Written Reflection","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

'Data Analytics: Strategic Decision Making' is a simulation in which each student will act as the brand manager for a laundry detergent. You are tasked with turning around the brand’s performance by using sophisticated analytic techniques to understand current issues and determine the best strategy for improving performance.

Using a dashboard that provides metrics on market share, profitability, competitor pricing, and demand by geographic region, you will devise your strategy by forecasting demand and then make decisions on production, pricing, positioning, promotional spending, and communication activities.

It is expected that all students will run the simulation (there are four rounds of decisions based on their analysis and resulting performance of prior years) and participate in the final debrief at the end of the simulation where specific student results are generated during the process.

The grade of this assessment is based on a reflection that describes your simulation attempt on the basis of two sets of questions.

There is a lot of data freely available online that we can use to analyse and learn more about the world, our societies and businesses. The insights that can be gathered are sometimes just interesting, while other times they are counter intuitive and profound. Often these learnings can impact the decisions you would make for your company, investments and more. This activity is an opportunity to find new data sources, apply some easy analyses and make it a habit to find new facts that will surprise yourself and colleagues.

This test will be of 1 hour duration, and will consist of 20 multiple choice questions and 5 short answer questions. It will cover the first 5 weeks of course materials.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"26dde14fdbc35450358b403c3a961965","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO8","cl_id":"26dde14fdbc35450358b403c3a961966","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"26dde14fdbc35450358b403c3a961967","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"2adde14fdbc35450358b403c3a961964","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"2adde14fdbc35450358b403c3a9619fd","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"2edde14fdbc35450358b403c3a961965","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"2edde14fdbc35450358b403c3a961966","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"2edde14fdbc35450358b403c3a961967","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"c3dd254fdbc35450358b403c3a961943","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Group","value":"Group"},"assessment_name":"Assessment 4: Data Preparation and Analysis","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"30","description":"

This group assessment is focused on generating value from our data. It consists of 2 related steps. 1. Initial Data Preparation/Analysis and 2. Data Analysis: Designing a dashboard/data story using Tableau Desktop.

1. Initial Data Preparation and Initial Data Set Analysis

Each group will work with a data set that needs to be prepared for analysis. The group will be provided with the data set at the beginning of the course (In Week 1 it will be published in your Moodle class site).

The purpose of this activity is to acquire the necessary skills for data preparation. The tasks to be done are:

  • Data Set analysis: the group must prepare an analysis of the data set that describes what needs to be done to obtain a trusted data source.
  • Data Preparation: after the analysis, you must create a new ready-for-analysis data set from the original data source using Tableau Prep Builder. You must apply all the required steps to solve all the identified issues/needs that have been described during the analysis (for example, create a new column, delete one column, change the type of a column or add additional data to your assessment).

2. Data analysis: Designing a dashboard/data story using Tableau Desktop

In this second step your team will be designing a dashboard/data story using Tableau Desktop.

Each group must create a dashboard and/or a data story that will help a user to make decisions (related to the specific case).

Preparation for and active participation in the workshops will provide you with the best foundation to learn in MNGT5232. Each week (including Week 1) there will be a discussion and some required preparation. In each workshop there will be periods where you are asked to discuss with other people in the class the application or insights of the allocated case study, and/or apply a particular theory or concept to a question in point.

contentlets.description:
Discusses how organisations create value within their operations. It shows how to analyse a company's processes in terms of capacity, lead time and variability, with the aim of achieving excellence in all dimensions. Learn how to develop strategies for improving supply chain performance, and apply the key techniques of project management.

This is a core course for the AGSM MBA.

Marketing Management","description":"

Marketing Management introduces you to the key principles and activities that are essential tools of every organisational leader and manager. The frameworks outlined in this course have been used by many large and small organisations to improve their marketplace performance.


You will be required to analyse the practices of a range of organisations as presented in case studies, simulations and guest presentations from marketing practitioners, by utilising the ideas presented in this course. At the end of this course, you should be able to view any business from a marketing-oriented perspective.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"97a2f8fedb471450358b403c3a9619fa","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Assessment 2: Case Notes (5 in total)","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"50","description":"

Submit a two-page case note per case 24 hours prior to the case discussion.

Each case note needs to address specific questions about the case. These questions can be found in Moodle in the relevant case package.

Each of the five case notes is worth 10%.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"53a27cfedb471450358b403c3a961901","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"53a27cfedb471450358b403c3a961902","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"53a27cfedb471450358b403c3a961903","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"5ba27cfedb471450358b403c3a961901","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"5ba27cfedb471450358b403c3a961902","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"13a27cfedb471450358b403c3a961906","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Assessment 1: Engagement (Preparation & Participation)","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"10","description":"

Preparation for and active participation in the workshops will provide you with the best foundation to learn in MNGT5251. Each week (including Week 1) there will be a discussion and some required preparation. In each workshop there will be periods where you are asked to discuss with other people in the class the application or insights of the allocated case study, and/or apply a particular theory or concept to a question in point.

You can contribute to the class discussion in different ways - for example, by:

  • identifying the key issues in the case, drawing on your reading of the case and the supplementary material
  • concisely explaining and justifying your ideas
  • listening to the contributions of your classmates and engaging them in a supportive and constructive debate
  • making links between ideas in the discussion and current business issues from the media.
","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"53a27cfedb471450358b403c3a961902","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"5ba27cfedb471450358b403c3a961901","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"5ba27cfedb471450358b403c3a961902","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"80b27cfedb471450358b403c3a96191a","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Group","value":"Group"},"assessment_name":"Assessment 3: Marketing Challenge (Presentation)","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

All students are required to participate in a Marketing Challenge in the final class. The objective of participation in this challenge is for students to apply and practise all of their learning in the course, and present these findings back to the class to facilitate shared learning.

This is an open book/open web challenge, and there is no special preparation required for this activity.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"53a27cfedb471450358b403c3a961902","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"5ba27cfedb471450358b403c3a961901","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"5ba27cfedb471450358b403c3a961902","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"93a2f8fedb471450358b403c3a9619fb","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"88b27cfedb471450358b403c3a96191e","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Assessment 1: Newshound Participation","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"10","description":"

The Newshound Activity is an opportunity for us to keep in touch with ‘real-time’ global marketing-related stories as they happen. While course notes and textbooks contain great and often timeless theory, thanks to the internet we can explore the globe for relevant material and share this with each other for discussion and debate.

At the start of our first week, your facilitator will post a Newshound Timetable that provides a slot for each student to post a newshound activity in their nominated week of the session. This ensures that we get an even spread, rather than all Newshounds being posted in Week 1 (or Week 10!).

For this activity, I would like each student to ‘sniff out' a current item in the news that is timely (say, a maximum of 12 months old) and relevant to the particular topic to which you will be assigned. You will then post a link to the item in the Newshound Forum and very briefly discuss the relevance of the item to the topic.

You also need to respond to anyone who comments on, or analyses, your Newshound post.

Note: To make this activity work, each student is expected to respond to at least one other Newshound post, offering an analysis of the article and the marketing issues it contains.

In summary, there are three tasks you need to undertake in this activity:

1. post your own Newshound

2. respond to anyone who comments on your Newshound post

3. respond to other Newshounds (at least one).

A Newshound forum will be provided on the Moodle site and will remain open all session. Your facilitator will kick it off with examples in the first week.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"53a27cfedb471450358b403c3a961902","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"9700757edb87d850eb6b147a3a961970","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/MNGT5251.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"MNGT5272","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"MNGT5272 - Managing People and Organisations","description":"

The organisations we work in are rich and complex organisms in which many interactions, relationships and processes are played out daily. The complexity of these interactions often makes them difficult to understand and manage.


This course focuses on generalist managers who manage people - some you manage formally, such as your subordinates and others informally, such as your peers and bosses. At the core of the course is characterisation and discussion of everyday functions and roles managers take part in, such as sense-making, sense-giving, decision-making, leading, motivating, planning, organising, mentoring, monitoring and influencing. Each Unit in this course covers a topic that contributes to your better undertaking of these managerial roles so that you can become a better manager of yourself, others, teams and organisations.


In this course, we will ask you to test your understanding of the concepts we introduce by examining your working life. This could involve analysing your actions, the actions of others, processes that occur within your organisation and key organisational events. You can use these activities to evaluate the concepts; that is, you should ask yourself:


  • how useful is this idea for me?
  • how can I modify this idea in light of my own experiences?
  • how can I apply this idea in my organisation?

This course is designed to introduce you to some of the key ideas, issues and debates about management and managing others within an organisation. In each Unit, you are introduced to a new issue/area of focus, but remember, each of the topics we will encounter in the course could be the focus for a whole course in itself. So, we aim to give you a flavour or introduction to each topic. Hopefully, the course will be a starting point for your understanding of management and managing others, rather than the end of your journey.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"6e6f057bdbb91c50eb6b147a3a96194e","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 1: Evidence-based management assessment of an organisational practice.","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

Your first assessment is a team assessment. You will be allocated to a team for this course, teams will be constructed to maximise diversity in experience, cultural background and gender. This assessment will centre on the Evidence-Based Management (EBM) process that is discussed in Unit 2. One organising key concept for your assignment will be the 6As of EBM. In the assignment, we will focus on the first four elements of asking, acquiring, appraising, and aggregating.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"1a6f057bdbb91c50eb6b147a3a96191e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"2e6f057bdbb91c50eb6b147a3a961929","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"6a6f057bdbb91c50eb6b147a3a96192c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"926f057bdbb91c50eb6b147a3a961924","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"0a6f057bdbb91c50eb6b147a3a961910","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 2: Organisational action learning review (OALR)","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"40","description":"

The purpose of this assessment is to give you the opportunity to apply the concepts learned in this course to your own organisational life.

Specifically,

  1. you will analyse a specific incident that you (or someone you observed) could have handled more effectively,
  2. explain the organisational context within which the incident happened, and
  3. logically derive from your analysis specific actions you will take to improve your management practice next time you encounter a similar event.

You should aim to draw on concepts from two to three Units of the course in your organisational action learning review (OALR).

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"1a6f057bdbb91c50eb6b147a3a96191e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"566f057bdbb91c50eb6b147a3a961921","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"6a6f057bdbb91c50eb6b147a3a96192c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"926f057bdbb91c50eb6b147a3a961924","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"a66f057bdbb91c50eb6b147a3a96192f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"de6f057bdbb91c50eb6b147a3a961926","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO8","cl_id":"e26f057bdbb91c50eb6b147a3a961932","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"426f057bdbb91c50eb6b147a3a961915","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Participation","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

The purpose of this assessment component is to help you develop your ideas formatively through individual work (reflections) while taking part in learning activities with your peers. It is based on contributions made during class.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"1a6f057bdbb91c50eb6b147a3a96191e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"6a6f057bdbb91c50eb6b147a3a96192c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"926f057bdbb91c50eb6b147a3a961924","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"866f057bdbb91c50eb6b147a3a961907","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Unit quizzes","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"10","description":"

As part of your assessment, you will also be required to complete online quizzes. For this purpose, in order to successfully complete the quiz, you will need to have thoroughly read and digested the materials.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"MNGT5282","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"MNGT5282 - Strategy","description":"

This course introduces you to the skills necessary to be a successful general manager. For the general manager, management is less about day-to-day operations of the firm, and more about positioning the firm, articulating a vision, and designing the firm to achieve competitive advantage. Throughout the course, examining issues essential for the firm's long and short-term competitive position will take centre stage.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"3d63e97fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619f7","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 3: Final exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"30","description":"

The final examination for this course is an online open-book exam taking place in the official exam period. It will be of two hours’ duration and is worth 30% of the total course assessment weighting.

The exam uses a combination of short answer and essay questions to test your knowledge of the core concepts from class and your ability to apply these concepts to business situations.

In the exam, you must answer two (and only two questions) from the options that are provided. These are essay questions. They require a well-structured and clearly argued response. Each question is worth 15 marks.

A sample exam will be posted towards the end of the course, with further details of the exam provided early in the Session.

1: Case presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

Towards the end of the course (typically Weeks 9 and 10), the class will be based on a series of live case studies. These case studies are part of the assessment for the course. Each group will be responsible for presenting a potential strategic response to a challenge that has been identified by a senior executive within that business. An executive or senior leader from the organisation will come to the class to listen to the presentation and to engage in the discussion. In some cases, the strategic challenge will be a current challenge for the organisation (in which case the executive will be looking for ideas from the presentation and discussion); in other cases, the issue will be one that the organisation has already solved (in which case you will be able to learn from the experience that the executive brings).

The details of the case will be available approximately one week before the presentation.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"1563e97fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619ce","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO8","cl_id":"2d63e97fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619e8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"6163e97fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619d1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO9","cl_id":"6963e97fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619eb","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"9963e97fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619c8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO10","cl_id":"a563e97fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619ee","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"ad63e97fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619d3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"d563e97fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619cb","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"ed63e97fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619e5","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"8163e97fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961994","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 1: Case Reflection","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

After the teams presentation and the discussion, each team  member is required to write an individual reflection.  The reflection needs to address two questions:

  1. How would you change your recommendations based on the insights that you have gained from the discussion?
  2. What have you learned about doing strategy in a real organisation?
","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"1563e97fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619ce","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO8","cl_id":"2d63e97fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619e8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"6163e97fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619d1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO9","cl_id":"6963e97fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619eb","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"9963e97fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619c8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO10","cl_id":"a563e97fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619ee","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"ad63e97fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619d3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"d563e97fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619cb","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"ed63e97fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619e5","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"8163e97fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619a5","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 2: Class-discussion contribution","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"20","description":"

You can contribute to the class discussion in different ways - for example, by:

  • identifying the key issues in the case, drawing on your reading of the case and the supplementary material
  • concisely explaining and justifying your preferred course of action
  • listening to the contributions of your classmates and engaging them in a constructive dialogue
  • making links between ideas in the discussion and current business issues from the media or material from other classes/courses.

Your participation will be evaluated after each class. I will use a four-point scale: (0) missed class, (1) attended class, (2) contributed to the case discussion, or (3) made a significant contribution to the case discussion. ‘Significant contribution’ can take a variety of forms, including moving the discussion forward, making insightful comments and connections to course materials, etc. The quality of your contribution is far more important than the quantity (i.e. you are not contributing to the class if you are talking for the sake of talking, and you are definitely hurting everybody including yourself). Note that repeated absences can have a large negative effect on the overall contribution grade.

 

Details

I expect you to be prepared for class and case discussions each week. I will often cold-call on people. If, for some reason, you are not adequately prepared for class and do not wish to be called on, please tell me prior to the beginning of class. To get the most out of the class and to be ready for cold calls, you should be highly prepared for every session.

You can also make contributions to class discussions through comments that you post on the weekly forum. For those who participate in this way, your contributions to the online forum will be used as part of your participation mark. Contributions to these forums is encouraged. Particularly valuable are links between the concepts covered in class and current business issues that are appearing in the media.

This course examines the design and use of management accounting tools for effective strategic management. Strategic-level management is about envisaging and realizing sustainable competitive advantage. To make decisions in aid of achieving sustainable competitive advantage, senior managers need business and market intelligence derived from a variety of analysis tools and frameworks. This course introduces you to a suite of strategically relevant management accounting frameworks and issues pertinent to these strategic analysis and decision making demands.

Financial-statement information is used in a wide range of business decisions. We will discuss financial statements from a user's perspective, and use a variety of tools to break apart financial reports into meaningful units for analysis, forecast financial statements, and value a firm's shares. We will also look at the role of managerial incentives and accounting rules in assessing the quality of financial statements.


The course is divided into five sections: (1) Information collection, (2) Processing information (accounting analysis), (3) Processing information (the role of incentives), (4) Forecasting, and (5) Valuation and decision-making. These sections will provide us with the structure we need to help us become more informed users of financial information.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"e863e97fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961940","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 1: Class participation","assessment_type":{"label":"Performance","value":"performance"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

You need to prepare case summaries for each case used in the course - specific questions will be provided to assist and direct you in preparing these. Without adequate preparation, you will find it difficult to contribute usefully in class and will risk a poor grade for class participation. I will also indicate opportunities for class participation through some minor research tasks to be discussed/presented in class.

The course will be taught in a discussion mode to facilitate thoughtful discussion of the cases. To get the most out of the course, you must be prepared for discussion every day. You should come to class with a list of questions on everything you do not understand, and you should be prepared to discuss your opinions on professional issues. In other words, you do not have to have a specific question in order to participate; I am very interested in your opinions.

You can participate in different ways. These include (but are not limited to):

  • identifying key issues in a case, based on your reading of the materials provided
  • describing relevant personal experience
  • making comments linked to the comments of other students and to the basic topic of discussion
  • listening to the contributions of your classmates and engaging them in constructive dialogue.

The quality of your contribution is far more important than the quantity. You should also use your name cards for the first six weeks of the course. You should be prepared for cold-calling in all class meetings, especially in class time devoted to discussion of the case studies and of the Analyst Report.

You will lose points for contribution if you use your phone in class or use your computer other than for course-specific tasks.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"5463a97fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619fe","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"9063e97fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961901","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO9","cl_id":"a063e97fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a96193a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"e863e97fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961931","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"0c63a97fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619da","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 2: Analyst report (Group)","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

The group project requires you to conduct a complete analysis and valuation of a publicly listed company. Your company can be listed on an overseas exchange, or (preferably) on the Australian Securities Exchange.

You cannot choose Woolworths, Qantas or Kathmandu. I would recommend that you avoid choosing a bank or a firm that has recently been involved in a large merger. This is because these firms are harder to value.

Meanwhile, you can find a list of all ASX sectors and constituent companies at the following website: http://www.asx.com.au/asx/research/companyInfo.do

The project requires you to conduct a complete analysis and valuation of the business. A key feature of the project is that it requires you to identify and obtain the relevant, publicly available information. Thus, in addition to being evaluated on your ability to apply the tools of analysis described in the course, you will also be evaluated on your ability to identify and obtain the relevant information. Your analysis should provide solid support for the assumptions and forecasts that drive your valuation. (Your valuation should use only publicly available information. Do not use inside information obtained from personal company contacts etc.) Do not use brokerage-house reports or other published sources that make investment recommendations.

Note: You need to clear your final selection with me before proceeding.

You will complete the mid-session exam during class. It will consist of several questions designed to assess your understanding of the material we will cover in the first half of the course. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"2863e97fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961934","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"5063e97fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a96192c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"5463a97fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619fe","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"9063e97fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961901","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"9c63e97fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a96192e","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"8c63a97fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619e3","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 4: Final assessment","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"30","description":"

You will complete the final assessment as a take-home project; it will be available at the end of our final class as a download in Moodle. It will consist of questions designed to assess your comprehension of the material we will cover in the course. You will need to show your detailed workings. You will hand in your take-home exam via Turnitin in Moodle. Further details of the process and submission date will be provided in the first class.

"}],"faculty_detail":[{"cl_id":"5a3a1d4f4f4d97404aa6eb4f0310c77a","published_in_handbook":{"label":"Yes","value":"1"},"name":"UNSW Business School","ext_id":"COMM","active":"true","parent":{"value":"","cl_id":null,"key":"name"},"code":"COMM","description":"Australia's leading Business School, creating the next generation of business thinkers, change-makers and entrepreneurs.","url":"http://www.business.unsw.edu.au","name_url":"UNSW Business School","name_no_url":""}],"requisites":[],"unit_offering":[{"fees_domestic":"","publish":"true","location":{"value":"","cl_id":null,"key":"name"},"name":"MNGT5321-8","clarification_to_appear_in_handbook":"","display_name":"","teaching_period":{"value":"Term 3","cl_id":"601633b7db7993009c2c403c3a9619ab","key":"name"},"attendance_mode":{"value":"","cl_id":null,"key":"description"},"quota_number":"","study_level":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"self_enrol":"true","academic_item":{"value":"MNGT5321","cl_id":"b253a97fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a96193a","key":"code"},"fees_commonwealth":"","fees_international":"","course_restrictions":"","cl_id":"7affad44db82d850358b403c3a961930"}],"academic_calendar_tooltip":"Consists of three standard terms, each with ten weeks teaching, and an optional five week summer term.  Some programs in Medicine, AGSM, and UNSW Global have different term dates.  See the university website for details.","academic_item_type":"Course","no_enrolment":"false","offering_detail":{"key":"pgrd","fees":{},"offering_terms":"","fees_table":"","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"MNGT5321","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"MNGT5321 - Advanced Managerial Finance","description":"

This course focuses on the role and usage of financial instruments. We begin by discussing financial options and their applications in corporate finance. We then introduce a general valuation framework for option-like contracts and apply it to real options. In the second half of the course, we discuss the implications of frictions and agency problems for investment and capital structure. The central theme in this part is how financial contracts, such as convertible bonds, can help resolve frictions and agency issues. A comprehensive case concludes each major section of the course to illustrate practical applications of the concepts.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"e353a97fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619a0","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 1: Group case report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"15","description":"

Each group will prepare one Case Report during the course.The assignment of cases to groups will be random. However, the written case should be different from the one for which the group will prepare the Case Presentation.The report should be limited to 15 pages including supplementary material such as figures and tables. The report should give clear answers to the questions (that will be distributed in class and posted on the course web page), state necessary assumptions, and explain the key steps in the analysis of the case. All members of the group will be graded equally on this assignment.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"1353a97fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961994","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"6f53a97fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961996","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"9753a97fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a96198e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"ab53a97fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961999","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"d353a97fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961991","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"e753a97fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a96199c","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"4f53a97fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a96196a","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 2: Group case presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"15","description":"

Each group will deliver one Case Presentation during the course. The assignment of cases to groups will be random. However, the presented case should be different from the one for which the group will write the Case Report. The presentation should be limited to 40 minutes (further constraints may apply depending on the number of students taking the class) and each member of the team should participate in the presentation. All members of the group will be graded equally on this assignment.

Details of the individual component of the case presentation will be provided in the first week of the course.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"1353a97fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961994","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"6f53a97fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961996","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"9753a97fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a96198e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"ab53a97fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961999","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"d353a97fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961991","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"e753a97fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a96199c","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"8753a97fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961980","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 3: Final exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"5","weighting":"40","description":"

The course concludes with a two-hour written Final Examination comprising several multiple-choice questions and two problem-solving questions with several subsections. This exam covers the complete course.

The exam is open book, and students are required to complete the exam individually.

The exam is worth 40 marks (the exact breakdown of the marks by problems will be specified on the exam paper) and contributes 40% to the overall course grade.

This course seeks to help students understand what venture capital is, what venture capitalists do, the way venture capital organisations work and why/how they play such a significant role in the economy. This course will alternatively take the perspectives of the venture capitalist and that of the entrepreneur.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"ea53a97fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a96192b","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 4: Final Exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"40","description":"

The final exam will take place in Week 13 at a time and location to be determined by the AGSM towards the end of the session.

The objective of the final exam is to test whether you have achieved the learning objectives of Units 1 to 12 of the course.

Participation will be assessed throughout the course and will relate to the case analysis discussions and in-class activities.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"1e53697fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619f5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO10","cl_id":"6253a97fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961913","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO11","cl_id":"6653a97fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961922","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"9253697fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619f0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"d653697fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619d4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"de53697fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619f2","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"7553697fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619bd","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 2: Case study","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

The objective of this assignment is to apply the ideas and principles developed in Units 1 to 4 of the course (general overview and assessment of investment opportunities).

Answers to the questions below are to be submitted via Turnitin and also handed in at the beginning of class in Week 5. Keep a copy to refer to in the class discussion.

  1. What information provided in the case makes this opportunity appear to be a good investment?
  2. What information about the company gives you concerns?
  3. What information do you need that you either don’t have or is very sketchy?
  4. Identify which issues are the most important to come to grips with; that is, if you don’t get a positive answer, you would not go forward with the investment.
  5. How would you go about getting the information you decide that you need?

If you believe that certain answers are better answered together, feel free to do so.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"1e53697fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619f5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO10","cl_id":"6253a97fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961913","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO11","cl_id":"6653a97fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961922","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"9253697fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619f0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO12","cl_id":"a253a97fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961925","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"d653697fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619d4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"de53697fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619f2","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"8e53697fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619c1","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 3: The venture capital method - Valuation problem set","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"25","description":"

You will be provided with further details on this assessment in class as well as some specific guidance during Unit 6.

This assignment is individual. As such, it must not be discussed with other students.

The objective of this assignment, mostly quantitative in nature, is to apply the techniques developed in Units 5 and 6 of the course (valuation in a venture capital context).

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"MNGT5325","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"MNGT5325 - International Finance","description":"

The course will provide information and analysis on the latest developments in the world of finance and their implications for business strategies. The course will provide live financial data and other information from NYU, The Wall Street Journal and The Financial Times to teach a number of issues that influence global finance and the way multinational companies build their global business networks, their activities and strategies. The course also brings a fresh perspective from eminent scholars from various leading business schools in the United States, Europe and Asia, including Nobel Laureate Robert Engle from NYU and others.


Some of the anlaysis and data offered in this course are part of the collaboration between the Institute of Global Finance at the UNSW Business School and the Volatility Institute at Stern Business School, NYU. The latest issues on global finance will be taught in this course, with presentations, videos and online financial data. The basic thrust of this course is to provide a framework within which the key global financial issues, including the operations of multinational companies, can be analysed. This course is designed to develop students understanding of the business and financial aspects of their main specialisation. The course prepares students for leadership roles and builds understanding of global financial forces that could influence the overall business environment. We also invite guest lecturers from industry, including experts from KPMG, to share their insights with students.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"e553697fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961982","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 2: Group Assignment","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

The group assignment is a great teamwork exercise that links this activity to practice one of the outcomes of this course which is to promote collegiality and working together as a team. Furthermore, this group project which is asking students to provide a report on the operations of a major multinational company, including issues with regard to business ethics, social responsibility, adherence to law and environmental issues will assist them to become more aware of global forces and cultural issues. These outcomes, in turn, could assist students to develop qualities that build the attributes of leadership in business strategy. Furthermore, this project will assist students to develop leadership qualities that demonstrate an inclusive and cohesive approach to each employee as being  valued and his or her potential talents being developed and utilised.  Reference to the Annual Reports of the multinational companies as part of this group project  will assist in highlighting the way business practices are applied and the way leadership and cultural factors are used to enhance business ethics and values for the company, its shareholders and its users and clients.

","learning_outcomes":[],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"8d53697fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961938","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 1: Class Participation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"25","description":"

Class participation is designed to ensure some of the outcomes of the course are practised and applied in the actual class. This includes outcomes such as communication and business knowledge. Students will be discussing some of the key global financial issues that influence the operations of both companies and the markets. Effective articulation of the issues to other students during the class and demonstration of business knowledge, as another outcome of this course,  will be applied as part of this process. 

Details

Each student will choose a particular topic or theme and make a presentation on it during the class. It could be a 5 minute presentation using PPT on any topic that is related to some aspects of global finance. We are flexible regardging the topic or theme that students choose. Those who do not feel confident to stand in front of other students are allowed to read out their presentation. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO12","cl_id":"e953697fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a96197e","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"b453697fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961934","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 3: Final Examination","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"45","description":"

The Final exam is designed to test students in a few of the key outcomes of this course, including problem-solving, business knowledge, business practice and factors that contribute to leadership in business, satisfaction of clients, factors that assist in increasing the market share of a business and the fulfilment of corporate responsibility.

Furthermore, the course materials and preparation for the final exam will provide an opportunity to students to demonstrate the attributes of course outcomes such as leadership, business practice, business knowledge and business ethics.

The objective of Marketing Strategy is to demonstrate the benefits of undertaking marketing within a strategic framework. At the end of the course students should be able to conduct a complete audit of the marketing environment facing the firm, understand how to generate new marketing options and develop defensive actions, and use the marketing mix and account management strategies to realise the various roles of products and services within the organisation.

contentlets.description:
The objective of this course is to supplement basic marketing and marketing strategy courses by focusing on problems and strategies specific to marketing of services. Problems commonly encountered in marketing services – such as difficulty in controlling quality, managing service failure and recovery situations and an inability to inventory – will be addressed. Strategies used by successful services marketers to overcome these difficulties will be discussed. By participating in this course, students will:

  • recognise the similarities and differences between the marketing of services and goods;
  • critically analyse service-related issues faced by real companies and offer viable solutions and gain a deeper appreciation of the number and extent of their own service encounters.
contentlets.title: Digital Business and Marketing Strategy

Leadership Concepts and Skills","description":"

The course will cover theories of leadership as well as group dynamics within a multi-cultural context. It also incorporates a strong practical and experiential component based on the recognition that leadership qualities and skills are linked to self-awareness, the ability to manage oneself in different situations, and a high level of interpersonal skills. In this context, participants will have the opportunity to assess and explore their leadership experiences and styles of communication with the aim to define areas of strength as well as areas that need further development.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"MNGT5374","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"MNGT5374 - Managerial Decision Making","description":"

The aim of this course is to improve decision-making skills and to provide strategies for further improvement in the future. We cover how individuals and groups make decisions and solve problems, individually and in organisations. By the end of the course, students will understand their own decision styles and personal dispositions, make decisions more deliberately and systematically, and will be able to use decision analysis techniques and group processes, integrate their values into their decisions, and generally, have increased confidence in their decision-making.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"2853297fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619d4","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 2: Assignment","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"50","description":"

The assignment (2,000 words) will offer a range of possible topics. Students will need to demonstrate a solid grasp of the theoretical foundations and the ability to consider how these might be applied in practice. The topics will be based on the ideas covered in class, including both the theoretical material and the practical tools. The assignment will be due on Monday 4 March. Standard MBA submission procedures (including treatment of late submissions) and referencing protocols will apply. Further details about the assignment, including marking criteria, will be provided in Moodle prior to the start of the session.

The take-home exam will cover all of the topics discussed in the course. It will be an open-book format. Questions will require students to integrate theoretical concepts and practical tools. The exam will take place in the exam period.

The success of any enterprise is largely determined by the quality of strategic decisions taken by its leaders and managers. These decisions directly affect the position, resource deployment and direction of the organization. In Strategic Change Leadership our focus is on seven critical key aspects of contemporary strategy: strategic planning - the game plan for change, organizational change, new ventures, diversification, turnaround, culture change, and execution. The purpose of this course is to provide you with an overview of key contemporary strategic management concepts and techniques in these areas. These themes provide you with a comprehensive perspective on advanced concepts of applied strategic management. The perspective taken throughout the course will be that of the chief executive charged with the accountability for formulating and implementing strategy for the entire organization.
