","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"MNGT5388","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"MNGT5388 - Negotiations and Strategy","description":"

Negotiations and Strategy introduces you to the theory and practice of negotiation. Topics include basic negotiation strategies, cross-cultural negotiation, and negotiating in teams. You will also learn about the impact of power, perception, cognition and emotions on negotiations. Students will have the opportunity to implement the course theories and concepts by participating in negotiation role plays. Students are encouraged to actively use negotiation theory and to reflect upon their own negotiation style and learning.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"a743297fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961929","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 1: Open-book quizzes","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"24","description":"

The open-book quizzes will confirm the extent of your engagement with course theory through a set of short-answer questions for each topic covered in Weeks 2 through 9 (eight quizzes in all). These scores will contribute three marks each to the final assessment (up to 24 marks in total).

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"0743e57fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619fa","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"4343e57fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619fd","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"4743297fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a96190c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO8","cl_id":"5b43297fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961917","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"3243e57fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619aa","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 3: Participation","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"16","description":"

This course is highly interactive and creates an unusually high mutual obligation among its students to attend on time and be ready to engage in negotiations and discussions. If one person does not observe this obligation, more than one person will be directly affected. Participation marks are intended to reward those students who properly and fully engage with all course activities. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"9343297fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a96190f","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"3243e57fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619dd","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 2 Part 1: Negotiation Plan","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"15","description":"

The negotiation literature identifies the crucial importance of proper planning and preparation for negotiation success. Therefore, an assessable planning exercise is included in this course.

You will analyse the assigned negotiation information and use it as the basis for developing a plan that will be used in the negotiation role play. The plan relates to the Job Offer negotiation, in Week 6.

Plans must be submitted via Turnitin no later than the beginning of the seminar in Week 6. It is also to be submitted in hard copy in class at the Week 6 seminar. You should have a copy or summary to use during the negotiation. Your summary should contain, at a minimum, the BATNA (best alternative to a negotiated agreement), resistance, opening and target points, and questions to ask and answer. Any summaries prepared will not be submitted for assessment.

Further assessment details and marking criteria will be available online by the start of the term.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"0743e57fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619fa","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO11","cl_id":"1343297fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961920","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"1f43297fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961914","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"4343e57fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619fd","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"4743297fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a96190c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO8","cl_id":"5b43297fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961917","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"9343297fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a96190f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"c743e57fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619f7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"df43297fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961911","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"7a43e57fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619ae","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 4: Team assignment","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"5","weighting":"30","description":"

The format of the negotiation in Week 11 is ‘team-on-team’. The Course Coordinator and Facilitator will assign students to a team ahead of this exercise. The team assignment task will be undertaken by each negotiating team as a group, and be submitted via Turnitin no later than the starting time of the Week 12 seminar. It is also to be submitted in hard copy in class at the Week 12 seminar.

The team assignment is designed to critically assess your awareness of your own skills (and awareness of those of your team and your opponents) in planning, implementing and analysing a longer, more complex, team-based negotiation. The analysis will be focused on students’ strategy and performance during the team negotiation in the final weeks of term. The assignment questions will be distributed in Week 10, ahead of the team negotiation in Week 11.

The team assignment gives you the opportunity to analyse yourself as a negotiator, as well as the impact of negotiating within a team, against a team. Areas that may be in the team assignment include (but are not limited to):

  • preparation: your team's, and that of the other team
  • the progression of events in the negotiation
  • the strategy and tactics adopted by both parties
  • the outcome you achieved and how your outcome compares against your team’s earlier goals and objectives
  • integration of the analytical tools and theory from the readings
  • impact of team dynamics on the negotiation
  • what you learned from the negotiation, upon reflection.

The most important elements are the integration of theory with your reflections on the negotiation process and a demonstration of critical analysis and self-reflection regarding all the parties to the negotiation. You should not waste words merely retelling events. Be sure to thoroughly justify your analysis using the appropriate literature and correct in-text referencing. You must use at least six references from literature listed on the course reading list within the text of your team assignment.

  • Assignments will be marked as one piece of work - same mark will be given to every team member
  • Appoint an editor whose job will be to make the assignment one consistent work / one voice
  • Do not merely cut and paste the work of several people into one document and then submit
  • Be clear about what question you are answering - If you would like to group some sections of your answer this is okay, but make it clear to the Course Coordinator and Facilitator, e.g. concession-making is tactical, therefore you may wish to combine your answer to questions 2.3 and 2.4 to avoid repetition and inefficient word usage.
","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"0743e57fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619fa","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO11","cl_id":"1343297fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961920","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"1f43297fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961914","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"4343e57fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619fd","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"4743297fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a96190c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO8","cl_id":"5b43297fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961917","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO12","cl_id":"6f43297fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961922","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"9343297fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a96190f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"c743e57fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619f7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"df43297fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961911","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"7a43e57fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619e1","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 2 Part 2: Self-reflective memo","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"15","description":"

In order to complete the learning associated with negotiation planning, a self-reflective memo is included in the assessments and integrated with the plan. Its purpose is also to facilitate personal insight into your negotiating style.

The task is to write a brief, critical evaluation of your involvement in the Job Offer negotiation and use the self-reflective memo to consciously recognise your weaknesses, note your strengths, and observe and learn from those of your opponent.

Self-reflective memos must be submitted via Turnitin no later than the start of the seminar in Week 7, which is the week after the actual negotiation upon which it is based. It is also to be submitted in hard copy in class at the Week 7 seminar.

The MBA Program in Entrepreneurship and Strategy is a program for individuals formulating, developing and commercialising ideas. This innovative program provides exposure to both the fundamentals of business and the practical aspects of identifying, evaluating, and moving business ideas forward. The program uniquely combines current students with innovators, VC groups and successful CEOs. A hands-on opportunity to learn about venture creation, resourcing, strategy and management, involving group work on a real venture and culminating in a pitch for resources to senior investors and entrepreneurs.

Entrepreneurial ventures are responsible for a significant share of growth, employment and value add in the economy. Entrepreneurial skills can be used to launch companies, revive acquired businesses, create new growth and cultural change within corporations and achieve significant social outcomes. Entrepreneurship in a flat world involves taking on the additional challenges of growing businesses across different cultures and managing a diverse mix of activities.

This dynamic course pulls together many of the components already learned in the MBA program, providing those with entrepreneurial aspirations the opportunity to realise their dreams.

contentlets.description:
The MBA Program in Entrepreneurship and Strategy is a program for individuals formulating, developing and commercialising ideas. This innovative program provides exposure to both the fundamentals of business and the practical aspects of identifying, evaluating, and moving business ideas forward. The program uniquely combines current students with innovators, VC groups and successful CEOs. A hands-on opportunity to learn about venture creation, resourcing, strategy and management, involving group work on a real venture and culminating in a pitch for resources to senior investors and entrepreneurs.

Entrepreneurial ventures are responsible for a significant share of growth, employment and value add in the economy. Entrepreneurial skills can be used to launch companies, revive acquired businesses, create new growth and cultural change within corporations and achieve significant social outcomes. Entrepreneurship in a flat world involves taking on the additional challenges of growing businesses across different cultures and managing a diverse mix of activities.

This dynamic course pulls together many of the components already learned in the MBA program, providing those with entrepreneurial aspirations the opportunity to realise their dreams.

This elective course on Strategies for Growth is a follow-up course to the core Strategy course offered at full time MBA program. Growth is possibly the most important concern of a firm after survival and the ability to manage growth has become a priority in the corporate agenda for sustaining competitive advantage. Strategies for Growth will provide students with an understanding of how to think strategically for growth. The course is structured around different growth strategies available to managers, including internal research and development, corporate venturing programs and corporate venture capital, joint ventures, mergers and acquisitions, and globalisation.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"MNGT5521","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"MNGT5521 - Financial Strategy","description":"

The focus of the course is on corporate financing: that is, how organisations create and use strategies in the financial markets to obtain funding for their activities, how they structure the contracts for the supply of capital, and how they link these to internal contracts with assets within the organisation. Additionally, we will explore the application of corporate finance theory in the business environment.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"1a43e57fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961924","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 4: Group Case Development Assignment","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"30","description":"

The Case Development provides you with the opportunity to explore in depth a particular area of the course by collating materials for, and creating a first write-up of, a real-world case designed to show a particular model or process in Financial Strategy. The case could be used in an MBA course in Financial Strategy for students with a good understanding of basic finance theory and some applications. The work is done in a self-selected group, so students are given a clear opportunity to share their learning, and learn from others, about the area. This exercise is intended to allow students to assess their engagement with the disciplinary knowledge and their critical and analytical thinking in a team environment.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"MNGT5522","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"MNGT5522 - Mergers and Acquisitions","description":"

The objective of this course is to introduce students to Mergers and Acquisitions (M&A) and the requisite knowledge for the development and execution of corporate transactions particularly within equity capital markets. Typical transactions include Takeovers, Acquisitions, Divestments, Initial Public Offerings and Private Equity. Each of these types of transactions will be addressed within the course.


Students will utilise common corporate finance tools and knowledge as applied within the context of considering, developing and executing M&A transactions. Participants will apply insights and skills taken from previous courses in finance.


The course includes negotiation within the context of M&A.


Case studies are used extensively throughout the course? including the use of current or recent transactions involving listed companies.


The course is a mixture of presentations, class discussions, case studies and group exercises all with an emphasis on the practical applications of corporate finance skills and knowledge within the context of M&A.

contentlets.description:
The objective of this course is to introduce students to Mergers and Acquisitions (M&A) and the requisite knowledge for the development and execution of corporate transactions particularly within equity capital markets. Typical transactions include Takeovers, Acquisitions, Divestments, Initial Public Offerings and Private Equity. Each of these types of transactions will be addressed within the course.

Students will utilise common corporate finance tools and knowledge as applied within the context of considering, developing and executing M&A transactions. Participants will apply insights and skills taken from previous courses in finance.

The course includes negotiation within the context of M&A.

Case studies are used extensively throughout the course? including the use of current or recent transactions involving listed companies.

The course is a mixture of presentations, class discussions, case studies and group exercises all with an emphasis on the practical applications of corporate finance skills and knowledge within the context of M&A.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"MNGT5540 - Business Modelling","description":"

This course will equip you with the practical skills to design and structure decision-making models. Students will be presented with a design methodology and the associated modelling techniques necessary to build models that are clear to use, powerful in application and address specific needs.


The models may be financial models, decision-making models, costing models or operational models. Regardless of their purpose, the course will also equip you to visualise results in well-structured dashboards that adhere to the needs of C-suite professionals and organisational decision-makers.


The techniques covered will focus on Microsoft Excel and would benefit anyone who wishes to better understand, build, analyse or maintain Excel-based models. Please note that this subject is taught with reference to Microsoft Excel in a Windows-based environment. This is a deliberate choice to reflect the reality that the modelling profession works almost exclusively in Microsoft Excel for Windows. Students who choose to take this subject with Apple-based Excel environments should be aware that many instructions involve detailed key strokes and Ribbon references that may not easily translate to an Apple environment.

contentlets.description:
This course will equip you with the practical skills to design and structure decision-making models. Students will be presented with a design methodology and the associated modelling techniques necessary to build models that are clear to use, powerful in application and address specific needs.

The models may be financial models, decision-making models, costing models or operational models. Regardless of their purpose, the course will also equip you to visualise results in well-structured dashboards that adhere to the needs of C-suite professionals and organisational decision-makers.

The techniques covered will focus on Microsoft Excel and would benefit anyone who wishes to better understand, build, analyse or maintain Excel-based models. Please note that this subject is taught with reference to Microsoft Excel in a Windows-based environment. This is a deliberate choice to reflect the reality that the modelling profession works almost exclusively in Microsoft Excel for Windows. Students who choose to take this subject with Apple-based Excel environments should be aware that many instructions involve detailed key strokes and Ribbon references that may not easily translate to an Apple environment.

This course concentrates on selected emergent topics, issues and debates in the areas of Management and Business. It will survey a range of established and emerging trends in theory and research within management literature. Specifically, the course aims to cover key topics in the fields of management, leadership, organisational behaviour, organisation theory, international business, innovation, entrepreneurship, marketing, economics and strategy.


The aim of this course is to offer the opportunity to develop insights about contemporary Management and Business field theories and models. Students will review and critically discuss major theories, frameworks and case studies, and how they relate to individuals, groups, and organisations. The course will assist students to compare, critique, and contribute to theoretical debate and to develop knowledge and understanding for future practical application.

Special Topic - International Business Strategy in Asia","description":"

Students may select a business topic to research under the supervision of an AGSM faculty member.


This one-to-one working arrangement allows the student to carry out in depth analysis of a topic relevant to his or her career aspirations.


A student may do an ISM if:


  • the student has a good academic record (with a minimum high credit average);
  • the study is in an area relevant to management;
  • the topic is in some way relevant to the student's career aspirations;
  • a suitable AGSM faculty member, or members, are available to supervise the work.

contentlets.description: Prior to the arrival of the first European settlers and convicts in January 1788, contemporary political and business leaders perceived Australia as terra nullis – the empty land. Today, it is often characterized as the “land down under”: remote, but somehow familiar. This course presents students with an introduction to Australia as a complex economy and society built from successive waves of migration, foreign investment and local innovation. Within 100 years of that first, fledgling penal colony, Australia was home to the world’s wealthiest city (in per capita income terms) and, more recently, Australia has uniquely enjoyed more than two decades of uninterrupted economic growth, while other OECD countries have suffered recession in the wake of the global financial crises. During the same two decades, Australia’s geopolitical focus has shifted from its historical and cultural ties to Britain and Europe to Asia. The course considers Australia’s economic and political systems, the nature of government-business relations, Australian cultural norms, and what they mean for doing business in Australia and Australia as a ‘gateway to Asia’.   The course flexibly blends input from instructors with input from students, mini-cases and exercises, facilitated discussions, unique experiential learning opportunities and corporate site visits to inform students how to operate Australia’s economic, political and social landscape and to challenge them to understand the ‘land down under’ as a place to do business.
contentlets.title: Doing Business in Australia

A student may do an ISM if:


  • the student has a good academic record (with a minimum high credit average);

contentlets.description:
Students may select a business topic to research under the supervision of an AGSM faculty member.

This one-to-one working arrangement allows the student to carry out in depth analysis of a topic relevant to his or her career aspirations.

A student may do an ISM if:

  • the student has a good academic record (with a minimum high credit average);
  • the study is in an area relevant to management;
  • the topic is in some way relevant to the student's career aspirations;
  • a suitable AGSM faculty member, or members, are available to supervise the work.
contentlets.title: Individual Study in Management

Students are supported in the completion of their project by an Academic Supervisor and the Program Office.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"MNGT5685","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"MNGT5685 - Crisis and Issues Leadership","description":"

This is an applied leadership course, contextualised to the contemporary environment. Delivery options include online, face-to-face (classroom) and experiential components. It will be offered as an elective course in the Full-time MBA Program.


We will provide students with a fundamental understanding of the complex nature of the contemporary business environment and the importance of strong, decisive and integrated leadership in times of crisis.


Learnings are brought to life through the use of contemporary case studies, with the course culminating in an experiential component in which students will be given the responsibilities of a fictitious company’s Crisis Management Team during a critical incident. Assimilation of course content will be put to the test in this simulation as participants deal with the emerging situation. The situation will require rapid decision-making and confident leadership in an ambiguous and rapidly evolving information environment, as well as the ability to interface appropriately with a wide variety of stakeholders – including confronting the media, employees, suppliers and the families of impacted people. 

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"f5ab21f3dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a96191b","name":"Blended in-person / online - Intensive"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"35","description":"

Individual Report – Select and analyse a business crisis. With reference to the course content, assess the manner in which this crisis was handled by the business’s leadership.  Describe whether you believe the business was adequately prepared for the incident. Identify key positive and negative aspects of the management of this crisis, providing justification as to why positive aspects were effective and proposing alternatives to identified negative aspects.

Written feedback will be given via Moodle.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"55abedb3dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619ce","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"9dabedb3dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619c5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"b1abedb3dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619d1","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"2cabedb3dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a96197e","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Experiential Component","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

Students will become the Crisis Management Team of a fictitious company facing an emerging crisis. In this capacity, they will be required to assimilate information inputs from multiple disparate sources and develop situational understanding within this ambiguous and rapidly emerging information environment in order to make decisions and communicate. Concurrently, the team will need to prioritise and satisfy demands from a wide range of stakeholders, ranging from the company board, to social and traditional media outlets, regulatory bodies, employees and the families of impacted personnel. ‘Hot’ debriefs will be conducted at key points throughout the activity to ensure that learnings are captured, discussed and shared.

Each student will be provided an opportunity to act in a leadership position, and they will be assessed upon this as well as their participation as team members. Assessment criteria will be based on their ability to apply the information taught during the program as both a team member and a leader.

Feedback will be a combination of verbal and written, primarily verbal for this assessment and given at the end of the experiential component.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"19abedb3dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619cb","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"55abedb3dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961991","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"55abedb3dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619ce","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"9dabedb3dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619c5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"b1ab21f3dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961912","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"b1abedb3dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619d1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"d9abedb3dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619c8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO8","cl_id":"fdab21f3dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961914","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"74abedb3dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961983","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Reflective Journal","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"10","description":"

This will be a reflective journal designed as a 'forcing function' to ensure that students spend time thinking about what they have experienced during the course and how it will be relevant to them in a leadership situation (either crisis or business as usual).

Written feedback will be given to students via Moodle.

Accounting and Financial Management","assoc_campus":null,"assoc_url":"/postgraduate/courses/2021/MBAX9120","assoc_class":"Course","assoc_award_titles":null,"assoc_state":"show","assoc_award_single":"","assoc_code":"MBAX9120","assoc_class_translated_subjects":"Course","assoc_faculty":"UNSW Business School","assoc_class_translated":"Program","assoc_duration_hb_display":"","assoc_current_version":{},"links":[]}],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"MNGT6210 - Accounting and Financial Management","description":"

The course provides a broad introduction to all aspects of the accounting function. The language of accounting and financial management is exacting. Our aim is to increase your familiarity with key components of this language and allow you to more effectively communicate with all organisational stakeholders. Users of accounting information may be typically classified as either external users (such as investors) or internal users (such as operational managers). Different users have different information needs. This course deals with the needs of these two main user groups and how the senior management of organisations can more effectively use accounting data to connect with them.


The subject will explore accounting techniques and terminology to equip students with sufficient conceptual and practical skills to make them, and any professional who may advise them, confident in their ability to understand and communicate complex financial strategies.


This subject also examines the design and operation of accounting systems. As a result, the course integrates ideas and concepts from accounting with a range of other disciplines and reveals how the effective use of financial information provided by such systems can improve organisational decision-making.


It is assumed that students have little prior knowledge of accounting and financial management.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"6333657fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961943","name":"Blended in-person / online - Intensive"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 2: Online Quiz 2","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"25","description":"

The quiz covers materials from Units 1 to 4.

It is primarily calculation-based and asks participants to apply their understanding of the components of the three primary financial statements, accrual accounting and the accounting equation.

It is done online via Moodle and contains 12 multiple-choice questions and a calculation-based question. The calculation-based question has multiple components. The duration of the quiz is 60 minutes and it may be started within a two-hour window from 6pm to 8pm (i.e. you can start the quiz at 7.30pm, in which case you would finish at 8.30pm).

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"1333657fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961922","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"5f33657fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961924","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"9b33657fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961927","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"0333657fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961903","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 3: Calculation and Description of Accounting Reports","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

Students will be required to create and comment on a set of financial reports. This is a team based assignment and details of how to form teams will be discussed 'in class'.

The assignment contains two parts.

Part 1 requires students to create an income statement and balance sheet from a series of accounting transactions. They are required to complete a firm's accounting cycle for a single period. Having created the financial statement, students are asked to provide a basic ratio analysis on the resultant financial statement and briefly comment on the ratios.

Part 2 requires students to create a budget from data contained within the question. Having created the budget, students are asked to provide an assessment of the budget and briefly comment on the value of the budget with regard to improving organisational decision making.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"1333657fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961922","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"5f33657fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961924","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"6733657fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a96193f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"9b33657fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961927","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"d733657fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a96192a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"db33657fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961939","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"4b33657fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961907","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 4: Online Quiz 3","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"35","description":"

The quiz covers materials from Units 1 to 10.

It contains both calculation-based questions and discursive questions and asks participants to apply their understanding of the components of financial accounting and the primary elements of management accounting.

It is done online via Moodle and contains 12 multiple-choice questions (these are primarily drawn from Units 6 to 10) and two calculation-based questions - one based on financial accounting and the second based on the application of management accounting practice. Each of the two calculation-based question have multiple components. The duration of the exam is 90 minutes and it may be started within a two-hour window from 6pm to 8pm (i.e. you can start the exam at 7pm, in which case you would finish at 8.30pm).

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"1333657fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961922","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"d733657fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a96192a","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"8333657fdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a96190c","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 1: Online Quiz 1","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"10","description":"

Multiple-choice questions

The quiz covers materials from Units 1 and 2.

It is primarily qualitative (limited calculations) and seeks to assess participants' understanding of the meaning of basic accounting terminology, the components of primary financial statements and their knowledge of the accounting equation.

It is done online via Moodle and contains 15 multiple-choice questions. The duration of the quiz is 30 minutes and it may be started within a two-hour window from 6pm to 8pm (i.e. you can start the quiz at 7.45pm, in which case you would finish at 8.15pm).

Business School","assoc_class_translated":"Program","assoc_duration_hb_display":"","assoc_current_version":{},"links":[]}],"search_title":"MNGT6211 - The Executive Blueprint","description":"

Executive Blueprint (EB) has been designed to enable you to be in learning mode (Heslin & Keating 2017*) regarding how you:


  • lead yourself to thrive in your MBA (Executive) Program, and
  • develop your capacity to forge a successful career as you make a positive impact on individuals, organisations, and the communities in which you work.

* Heslin, P A & Keating, L A 2017, 'In learning mode? The role of mindsets in derailing and enabling experiential leadership development', The Leadership Quarterly, 28, pp. 367-384.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"applies_to_all","name":"Assessments"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Class contributions","assessment_type":{"label":"Attendance","value":"attendance"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"25","description":"

High-quality class contributions build a productive learning environment for yourself and your class colleagues through both your video-based and face-to-face interactions, as well as your written feedback and evaluations of other students’ future career presentations. 

Examples of meritorious class contributions include:

  • attending your videoconference, residential, and future career presentation session on time and fully prepared
  • responding positively to invitations to contribute to class discussions and activities
  • proactively making succinct comments during discussions that demonstrate accurate knowledge and application of course concepts
  • actively listening to others, building on their responses, and supporting their active participation
  • sharing the limited available airtime for contributing to discussions
  • asking insightful or clarifying questions, based on having digested course requirements and assigned Readings, as well as having reflected upon the assigned Activities
  • providing helpful peer coaching, during both formal exercises and on relevant informal occasions, during our residential workshop
  • providing high-quality, anonymous, written feedback on the strengths of your colleagues' Future Career Presentations and how they may have been even better
  • adhering to the guidelines for providing peer evaluations of the Future Career Presentation delivered by about six class colleagues.

Note: The first five of these examples pertain particularly to our videoconference, the first seven are relevant during our residential, and the final two pertain particularly to our FCP session. You will learn about the nature of high-quality feedback on strengths and areas for improvement during our residential.

Several activities during our residential will develop your ability to make effective class contributions during EB … and all your subsequent AGSM classes. Peer feedback and evaluations will be collected on the extent to which you helped build a positive learning environment during the residential workshop.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"0e55e9b3dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961935","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"4655e9b3dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96192d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"8255e9b3dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961930","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"8e55e9b3dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96195d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"ca55e9b3dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961960","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"6555a9b3dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619fd","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Learning review","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

Summary

The Learning Review will test your comprehension of course concepts via your application of them to improve your managerial skills. One purpose of the Review is to provide you with the opportunity to distill and demonstrate what you have learned about how to improve your effectiveness as a (future) manager and leader. A second purpose is to ensure that you (and your class colleagues) thoughtfully complete the assigned Readings and associated Activities before your residential workshop so that you are all fully equipped to:

  1. learn through actively engaging in the workshop activities
  2. facilitate your class colleagues' participation and learning in the workshop.

Your Learning Review will include five questions, from which you will choose four questions to answer. Each question will be marked out of 10 and be worth 5% of your final course grade. The questions will focus on selected sections of assigned Readings and Activities from Units 1 to 6.

Details

Thoughtfully completing the relevant assigned Readings and Activities will enable you to be well-prepared for the Learning Review. The material that may be included in your Learning Review will be indicated by your facilitator and discussed during your videoconference. You will complete a sample Learning Review question during your videoconference, based on your thoughtful completion of Unit 1. Another sample question and ingredients of a strong answer will be provided on the course Moodle site after the videoconference.

To further help you succeed, at the commencement of your closed-book Learning Review, you will be alerted to the topics of the five pairs of questions covered in the Review. You will have 10 minutes to:

  • review your relevant Activity responses and your notes regarding the five learning review topics
  • select the four questions you will answer
  • take notes on a single sheet of blank paper that you will be able to keep with you when all other materials are put away before the Learning Review begins.

In order to not disrupt the workshop flow and learning experience of your course colleagues, no extra time will be granted to anyone who arrives late and there will be no make-up Learning Review.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"0e55e9b3dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961935","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"4655e9b3dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96192d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"ca55e9b3dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961960","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"ce55e9b3dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961932","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"ad55e9b3dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961901","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Peer Coaching","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

Summary

During the residential workshop, you will engage in a series of activities to incrementally enhance your peer-coaching skills and create a coaching development plan (CDP). You will also develop a Managerial Skill Development Plan (MSDP). For about a month following the residential, you will aim to be in learning mode as you implement your MSDP. On two occasions during this period, you will meet with an assigned peer coach who will:

  • Coach you on your MSDP implementation, while implementing their CDP
  • Be peer coached by you on their MSDP implementation, while you implement your CDP.

Soon after these peer coaching sessions, you will reflect upon and analyse your strengths and growth edges in implementing your MSDP and in serving as a peer coach, before deriving from your analysis SMARTER+ next steps in both roles.

Details

Your preparation for the residential workshop and your participation in the experiential learning activities during the workshop will provide the foundations for these peer-coaching activities. A central goal in the residential is to encourage and enable you to develop your coaching skills and integrate them in both your self-coaching and your coaching of others. The two peer-coaching sessions and your reflections on them will give you opportunities to:

  • enhance your understanding of how coaching can enable learning and development
  • further cultivate the coaching skills that you worked on during the residential workshop, as defined in the CDP you create.

Further details about planning and conducting your peer coaching sessions will be available in your Moodle class.

Written Reflections

The reflection stage of action learning and the recording of related insights is generally best done as soon as possible after the ‘action’ (Heslin & Keating 2017). Thus, strive to reflect and make notes within 24 hours of each peer-coaching session on what you did well, could have done better, and plan to do differently going forward as a coachee (to achieve your MSDP) and as a coach (by refining and implementing your CDP). Then, before the due date for each part of the assessment, write up and submit via Moodle a reflection (up to 500 words, including the headings and prompts on the prescribed template). In your reflections, address:

As a coachee:

(i)   What I learned about my strengths and growth edges from conceptually analysing the results of implementing my MSDP, and

(ii)   What I plan to do next to continue making progress in relation to my development goal, as logically derived from my analysis in part (i).

As a coach:

(iii) What I learned about my strengths and growth edges from conceptually analysing the results of implementing my CDP, and

(iv) What I plan to do next to further improve my coaching effectiveness, as logically derived from my analysis of part (iii).

Developmental Feedback

You will receive developmental commentary feedback and a mark out of 10 for your Assessment 3a, before you submit Assessment 3b. To facilitate your learning, a prime focus of this commentary feedback will be identification of areas where you might have more strongly addressed the assessment criteria. You are meant to apply what you glean from the feedback received on your Assessment 3a when writing up your Assessment 3b, rather than literally respond to any rhetorical questions raised in it.

You will receive some brief overall comments and a mark out of 20 for your Assessment 3b within 10 working days of submission.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"8255e9b3dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961930","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"bd55e9b3dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961912","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Future career presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"25","description":"

Summary

Career goals are more likely to be realised when you can (a) authentically and passionately describe them, (b) vividly imagine you have already achieved them, and (c) reflect on what you may have done to achieve them.

Your Future Career Presentation will give you the opportunity to: 

  • work towards harnessing these principles
  • reflect on what you consider to be the most useful course concepts for enabling your career and precisely how you might apply them to frame and achieve your career goals
  • practise being in learning mode as you work through several iterations of rehearsing your presentation, and then rehearsing it again
  • enhance your skills in communicating with authenticity, presence, and charisma in connecting with your audience.

Your task

Imagine that it is three to five years from now (you decide your targeted timeframe) and you have achieved your career ambitions! It is an EB class reunion and you have agreed to spend three minutes sharing with your class colleagues:

1. Your place under the sun and why it’s a great fit: Proudly describe your career role and how it fulfils your major career preferences.

2.    What you did to apply three course concepts to get you there. Be specific about what you did, why, and with what results.

Further details about developing, polishing, uploading, and delivering your Future Career Presentation will be made available in Moodle.

Modelling","description":"

There is an explosion of data in the business workplace, but very few managers are equipped with the quantitative skills to make effective use of this data. This course develops expertise in a standard set of statistical and graphical techniques, which will be useful in analysing data. These techniques are widely applied in a number of areas of management, including marketing, finance and economics. The course provides a change in mindset from "statistics can be used to show anything" to "statistics provide a methodology to cope with uncertainty" via the art of statistical thinking, that is, the ability to collect, understand and use data.

A work-based project is a key part of the course.

There are two saturday workshops in DASM. They are compulsory.

There is an explosion of data in the business workplace, but very few managers are equipped with the quantitative skills to make effective use of this data. This course develops expertise in a standard set of statistical and graphical techniques, which will be useful in analysing data. These techniques are widely applied in a number of areas of management, including marketing, finance and economics. The course provides a change in mindset from "statistics can be used to show anything" to "statistics provide a methodology to cope with uncertainty" via the art of statistical thinking, that is, the ability to collect, understand and use data.

A work-based project is a key part of the course.

There are two saturday workshops in DASM. They are compulsory.

Any business or organisation is concerned with delivering value to its customers or clients. A company's 'operations' are the direct processes that it uses to create value. These involve transforming various types of inputs into outputs. Operations management is the task of managing these processes. Each company or organisation will have a unique set of operations. This course is concerned with the fundamentals of operations management, covering both service industries and manufacturing. The aim is to give you a set of frameworks and concepts you can use to understand the operations functions and strategies of any company. The course examines the processes at the heart of operations management and ways of achieving excellence. It also looks at the supply chain; both the control of inventory and the way in which coordination between supply chain partners can be achieved. The course ends with the investigation of operational challenges involved in managing projects.

This course has two compulsory saturday workshops.

Marketing Management","description":"

Marketing Management is designed to introduce you to the full range of activities performed by a marketing-oriented manager. This subject is designed to introduce you to the key principles and activities necessary for you to have an appreciation of the importance of the role that marketing plays in the toolkit of every organisational leader and manager. The framework outlined in this course has been used by many large and small organisations to improve their marketplace performance. You will be required to analyse the practices of organisations in the marketplace, including your own organisation, and of your competitors, in co-creating value with customers and clients by utilising the ideas presented in this course. At the end of this course, you should be able to view any organisation from a marketing-oriented perspective.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"2c16c0f2dbbfd850eb6b147a3a96194d","name":"Blended in-person / online - Intensive"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 1: Organisation and environmental analysis","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

Scenario
You should consider the organisation from the perspective of an outside consultant who is hired to critically evaluate its current marketing position and operating environments. The report should provide an overview of the organisation, as well as detail the type of orientation towards marketing it takes. You are also required to examine and analyse the context and environments in which the organisation operates (its industry and the macro-environmental forces impacting on the industry), and critically examine how it learns about the 5Cs.

Importantly, the report shouldn't just focus on what the organisation is doing now and what its current orientation to marketing is, but should also assess whether its strategies and orientation should change in the future.

You may find the Marketing Audit template provided in Moodle to be useful. Though we have not touched on every issue addressed in the Marketing Audit, it may help you think through various aspects of the organisation.

Note: If the organisation has many offerings, you should select one and provide more depth on that offering, rather than being very general about the entire organisation.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO8","cl_id":"241604f2dbbfd850eb6b147a3a961949","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"241604f2dbbfd850eb6b147a3a96194a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"2c1604f2dbbfd850eb6b147a3a961948","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"2c1604f2dbbfd850eb6b147a3a96194a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"2c16c0f2dbbfd850eb6b147a3a96194e","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"381604f2dbbfd850eb6b147a3a96195a","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 2: Marketing strategy development","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

This assessment requires your team to apply action learning principles in an applied setting (an online simulation). It will enable you to practise using key concepts, models and frameworks from Units 1 to 12 in the applied setting and to generate insights through applying a test-learn approach and reflecting on the outcomes. 

Specifically, the assessment requires that you and your team collaborate to make and implement marketing-management decisions, then reflect and learn from the outcomes of those decisions. To do so you will need to:

  • identify a series of marketing models, concepts and frameworks from the course materials that you see as being useful and helpful in understanding the scenario and in informing your marketing decisions
  • apply these models to the facts and evidence provided for the scenario in order to analyse and interpret the marketing environment detailed in the materials provided for the simulation
  • form a hypothesis (or series of hypotheses) about the market and the likely effect of applying key concepts, models and frameworks from the course in the scenario
  • implement a series of marketing decisions based on your hypotheses in the simulation, observe the results of these decisions and derive insights from the results (in other words, set a marketing strategy, implement and modify the strategy over time, observe and interpret the results of the strategy)
  • derive and share insights about the practices of marketing based on what the team observes from implementing the strategy over time (try to explain what happened and why it happened)
  • communicate these insights about the practices of marketing to the Class Facilitator.

Your group must be formed by self-selection and agreed with your Class Facilitator by Week 5. A group may only be formed between students having the same Class Facilitator.Your Class Facilitator will provide details regarding the number of people required per group, and will assist if you are unable to form a group.

Your group will participate in a briefing, familiarisation and practice round of decision-making in Weeks 5 and 6. Over Weeks 7 to 11 your group will analyse the market and changes that come from decisions made by your group and competitors, analyse the results of your strategies, and collaborate to make and implement a series of marketing decisions designed to drive the marketing success of the organisation in the simulation.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO8","cl_id":"241604f2dbbfd850eb6b147a3a961949","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"241604f2dbbfd850eb6b147a3a96194a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"2816c0f2dbbfd850eb6b147a3a96194f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"2c1604f2dbbfd850eb6b147a3a961948","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"2c1604f2dbbfd850eb6b147a3a961949","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"2c1604f2dbbfd850eb6b147a3a96194a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"2c16c0f2dbbfd850eb6b147a3a96194e","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"811604f2dbbfd850eb6b147a3a961961","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 3: Final major assessment","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

The final assessment for this course will consist of two compulsory questions requiring answers with a total overall word limit of 2,000 words. The questions will be broad in scope and are designed to enable you to apply content (concepts, models and frameworks) from across the entire course (i.e. Units 1-12).

One of the questions will relate to a case study; the other question will be broader in scope and will enable you to draw on your own observations and experience. The case study will be provided in Moodle in Week 12 to enable you to prepare and analyse the case prior to the paper itself becoming available.    

A sample of a previous final assessment will be provided in Moodle towards the end of the session.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO8","cl_id":"241604f2dbbfd850eb6b147a3a961949","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"241604f2dbbfd850eb6b147a3a96194a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"241604f2dbbfd850eb6b147a3a96194b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"2c1604f2dbbfd850eb6b147a3a961948","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"2c1604f2dbbfd850eb6b147a3a96194a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"2c16c0f2dbbfd850eb6b147a3a96194e","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"a01604f2dbbfd850eb6b147a3a96194e","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 4: Online participation through dialogues","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"10","description":"

This assignment provides you with an opportunity to discuss the concepts, theories and frameworks of the course, and their application in a practical setting, such as organisations appearing in the media and from your own observations and experience, and to learn from students working in other industries. 

There are 10 assessable online dialogues, and each is weighted equally; in other words, each dialogue is worth one mark. Dialogue 1 requires you to introduce yourself to the Class Facilitator and other students. The remaining dialogues will require a response to a question about the course materials, posed by the facilitator.

Each posting will be given a grade of Satisfactory or Unsatisfactory and represents one mark if graded Satisfactory.
Further advice is given in the Online Learning Guide, which can be found in the Resources area of Moodle.

  • How does my group function, and how can it be more effective?

The MNGT6303 AGSM Masterclass is a new elective has a strong emphasis on shaping the agenda of the future. It provides MBA candidates with injections of global thought leadership, future scenario planning, frameworks and conceptual tools as well as clinics to solve real dilemmas. The Series consist of ½ day workshops jointly facilitated by industry leaders and academic staff on different contemporary topics. Six workshops will be offered each year.  Over a maximum of 24 months students need to attend five and successful complete assessment tasks. Topics will vary each year.  Example topics include: Digital disruption/ disruptive technology; Design thinking; Systems thinking; Agility; Operational excellence; Social media strategy; ‘big data’; Storytelling and narrative; Creativity; Start-ups.

It provides MBA candidates with injections of global thought leadership, future scenario planning, frameworks and conceptual tools as well as clinics to solve real dilemmas. The Series consist of ½ day workshops jointly facilitated by industry leaders and academic staff on different contemporary topics. Six workshops will be offered each year.  Over a maximum of 24 months students need to attend five and successful complete assessment tasks. Topics will vary each year.  Example topics include: Digital disruption/ disruptive technology; Design thinking; Systems thinking; Agility; Operational excellence; Social media strategy; ‘big data’; Storytelling and narrative; Creativity; Start-ups.

The underlying theme of this course is that a business must add value. Those that do not will either be forced to change or cease to exist. The course addresses the questions:


  • What is value, how is it measured and how does a well-run business create or add value?

In examining value, you will be introduced to the three basic ideas in finance:


  • the time value of money, diversification and arbitrage.

contentlets.description:
The underlying theme of this course is that a business must add value. Those that do not will either be forced to change or cease to exist. The course addresses the questions:

  • What is value, how is it measured and how does a well-run business create or add value?

In examining value, you will be introduced to the three basic ideas in finance:

  • the time value of money, diversification and arbitrage.

Foundations of Managerial Skills","description":"

FMS is a 12 week course that includes a 3 day compulsory residential.


The course is an academically-grounded orientation to the AGSM MBA (Executive) program. It is intended to provide a cohort experience and to help students acquire a range of useful strategies and skills for enhancing their managerial effectiveness, as well as for engaging productively with the MBA(Executive) course concepts and their colleagues throughout their program. The three themes addressed are managing your learning, learning together, and managerial skill development.


Learning in this course occurs through a combination of mindful engagement with reading course materials and assigned articles, completing written exercises, self-assessments, repeated 360 degree feedback, peer coaching, team-based case analysis, skill development planning, and action learning.


Please Note: Existing AGSM students who have already completed any MBAX or MNGT coded courses will need to contact the AGSM Student Experience Team for assistance with enrolment into this course. 02 9931 9400 studentexperience@agsm.edu.au

contentlets.description:
FMS is a 12 week course that includes a 3 day compulsory residential.

The course is an academically-grounded orientation to the AGSM MBA (Executive) program. It is intended to provide a cohort experience and to help students acquire a range of useful strategies and skills for enhancing their managerial effectiveness, as well as for engaging productively with the MBA(Executive) course concepts and their colleagues throughout their program. The three themes addressed are managing your learning, learning together, and managerial skill development.

Learning in this course occurs through a combination of mindful engagement with reading course materials and assigned articles, completing written exercises, self-assessments, repeated 360 degree feedback, peer coaching, team-based case analysis, skill development planning, and action learning.

Please Note: Existing AGSM students who have already completed any MBAX or MNGT coded courses will need to contact the AGSM Student Experience Team for assistance with enrolment into this course. 02 9931 9400 studentexperience@agsm.edu.au

This course explores selected theories and concepts of change management. You will identify the key skills you need to lead and implement change. We explore different perspectives on managing change, your personal change competencies, how to build readiness for change, change leadership, action research as a means of driving change, and strategic change. The course helps you to develop skills in these areas and broadens your competence to help organisations manage change. It uses a mixture of group-based activities, personal reflection and experiential exercises to explore a wide range of topics.

This course emphasises management rather than technology. It helps you understand how information technology can, and should, fit into your overall business plan. The course addresses two key questions:


  • How does information technology help or hinder the profitability of operations?
  • How can information technology support and leverage business strategies?

To answer these questions, you will acquire tools and techniques you can use to improve the fit between information technology and everything else in your organisation. You will also examine recent developments in e-business and the nature of networked organisations.

contentlets.description:
This course emphasises management rather than technology. It helps you understand how information technology can, and should, fit into your overall business plan. The course addresses two key questions:

  • How does information technology help or hinder the profitability of operations?
  • How can information technology support and leverage business strategies?

To answer these questions, you will acquire tools and techniques you can use to improve the fit between information technology and everything else in your organisation. You will also examine recent developments in e-business and the nature of networked organisations.
contentlets.title: IT and Organisational Performance

Please note that this course is not currently being offered. The course follows a detailed case study that follows the life cycle of a medium-sized enterprise. The case study is designed to be realistic as well as rich in legal issues of relevance to all varieties of enterprise. The initial focus of the course will be to get students to consider the variety of relationships created by commercial activity and understand the way in which legal principles apply to these relationships. Thus the course will involve relationships among and between: Co-venturer Managers vis a vis shareholders, stakeholders, employees, consumers and regulators/government, ordinary commercial parties dealing at arm's length, citizens (including corporate citizens) and the State. The course will, aside from teaching students the essential principles of law in key areas (as derived from statutes and case law), teach students how to work with legal principles in a practical manner. We will therefore focus on the process of bargaining "within the shadow of the law", mediation and negotiation and use of extra-legal and self-help remedies as means of managing legal and business risks. The course will also require students to consider the way in which the law interacts with ethical and sound managerial practice. You will be exposed to legal issues as they emerge in the real world and learn how to be a more informed and efficient user of the services of legal professionals to manage those issues.

contentlets.description: Please note that this course is not currently being offered. The course follows a detailed case study that follows the life cycle of a medium-sized enterprise. The case study is designed to be realistic as well as rich in legal issues of relevance to all varieties of enterprise. The initial focus of the course will be to get students to consider the variety of relationships created by commercial activity and understand the way in which legal principles apply to these relationships. Thus the course will involve relationships among and between: Co-venturer Managers vis a vis shareholders, stakeholders, employees, consumers and regulators/government, ordinary commercial parties dealing at arm's length, citizens (including corporate citizens) and the State. The course will, aside from teaching students the essential principles of law in key areas (as derived from statutes and case law), teach students how to work with legal principles in a practical manner. We will therefore focus on the process of bargaining "within the shadow of the law", mediation and negotiation and use of extra-legal and self-help remedies as means of managing legal and business risks. The course will also require students to consider the way in which the law interacts with ethical and sound managerial practice. You will be exposed to legal issues as they emerge in the real world and learn how to be a more informed and efficient user of the services of legal professionals to manage those issues.

International Business","description":"

The forces of globalisation have increased the permeability of traditional boundaries around countries, economies and industries. These forces include the expansion of international trade and investment, the growth of multinational corporations (MNCs), the ability of information and communications technology to span time and distance, and the shift of the worldâ??s economic centre of gravity from the West to Asia. Because of globalisation, the environment of business is now more complex, more dynamic, more uncertain and more competitive than ever before.


This course examines important strategic, organisational and operational issues from the perspective of managers working for local Australian firms or subsidiaries of MNCs based in Australia, as well as entrepreneurs who are looking to expand their venture overseas. Its main objective is to develop an understanding of the international business opportunities and challenges facing these firms and individuals, and how they can best address these issues when competing in the global marketplace.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"5c15c872dbbfd850eb6b147a3a9619ad","name":""},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 2 Part B: Final Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

In the final report, continue the work you started in Assessment 2: Part A - the presentation. This report has several specific sections that you need to include. These are detailed below.

1.    The first part of your report presents the country’s PESTEL (Political, Economic, Social, Technological, Environmental and Legal) factors and how these create business opportunities or challenges for Australian firms.

2.    The report should  focus on a small number of most important factors (e.g. demographic factors and labour cost for a labour-intensive project, and internet infrastructure for an offshore IT support hub), instead of giving equal weight to a large number of factors.

3.    The second part of your report should propose a plan of actions for an Australian firm to enter and conduct business in the country examined. There are two options to organise this section of your report:

    Option 1:

       If your project is the foreign expansion of a well-established firm, your report might include, but not be limited to, the following sections:

•     Recommended business investment/operation (e.g. R&D) and rationale

•     Recommended entry mode/strategy (e.g. joint venture) and rationale

•     Recommended organisational structure for the operation and rationale

•     Recommended human resource plan and rationale

•     Follow-up action and next steps.

     Option 2:

•     If your project is a start-up venture or born-global, you can refer to the Tool Box in Unit 10 (page 8) which provides you with the Business Model Canvas comprising the factors you need to address such as customer segments, customer relationships, channels, value propositions, key activities, key resources, key partners, cost structure and revenue structure. Your report should address these issues in an international context.

Your report should also include:

•     An executive summary (fewer than 150 words)

•     A brief description of the firm (can be real or hypothetical) and industry

•     A conclusion that draws together details of the report, briefly detailing the main findings.

Use of tables and figures is highly encouraged, with all tables and figures being numbered, titled and explained thoroughly in text. Bullet points can be used sparingly, but each point requires clear explanation in text.

Part B will be assessed as a group.

Much of the learning in this course comes from interaction between participants. Participation is evaluated by:

a.    face-to-face contribution to the intensive weekends (10%) and

b.    contribution to Moodle forums (15%), e.g. quality of the Opinion Piece and replies to others’ Opinion Piece.

Students need to demonstrate a good knowledge of the Unit being discussed, and make an effort to constructively facilitate dialogue between class members.

The quality of contributions to the class discussion will be reflected in the marks for participation. Specifically, students can:

1.    prepare for the intensive weekends by reading course material thoroughly and carefully

2.    act as a member of the discussion panel volunteerily or by invitation

3.    present and share their own business case with the class

4.    introduce guest speakers to the class

5.    post articles or other information related to this course on Moodle forums

6.    actively participate and lead group projects

7.    complete any specialised forum activities such as the ‘opinion piece’ activity in Week 7. Each student will publish an Opinion Piece (500 words approx.) in the Moodle forum to elaborate on their critical thoughts about an issue related to international business and globalisation. To express your view and also stimulate others’ thoughts, an interesting and thought-provoking topic and engaging writing style are essential. Readers are encouraged to reply to opinion pieces and these replies will be evaluated in terms of their quantity and quality. When publishing your article on Moodle, please use the article title as the title of your thread, and the IB class you are in (e.g. Sydney Intensive INT 1) before the article, because this forum is visible to students from all IB classes for a collective learning experience. For typical business articles by columnists, please see http://www.biznews.com/category/columnists/lucy-kellaway/. No referencing is needed.

Note that in the intensive weekends, having a clear name tag is essential for the Class Facilitator to record the participation mark accurately.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"d415c872dbbfd850eb6b147a3a9619af","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO8","cl_id":"d415c872dbbfd850eb6b147a3a9619b0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"d415c872dbbfd850eb6b147a3a9619b1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"dc15c872dbbfd850eb6b147a3a9619af","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"dc15c872dbbfd850eb6b147a3a9619b0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"dc15c872dbbfd850eb6b147a3a9619b1","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"70154c72dbbfd850eb6b147a3a961966","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 2 Part A: Interim Presentation of Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

The major assessment piece in this course is a team project looking at Internationalisation. This assessment has two related parts: a presentation (Part A), and a final report (Part B). In addition, there is a separate opportunity to evaluate your peers’ input to the team processes and work.

Student teams will be formed to reflect cultural and industry diversity at the beginning of the course. Each team of students will consider themselves as the internationalisation project team of an Australian firm, and select a country and conduct an assessment of its attractiveness and feasibility for this Australian firm in a specific industry (e.g. medical devices) to invest and do business there.

To ensure that no two teams will be conducting an assessment of the same country or industry, team coordinators should email the Course Coordinator (Email: janexjq@unsw.edu.au) the team’s country selection (with first and second choice) at the earliest convenience, and the selection approval will be made on a first-come-first-served basis, according to the date and time the email is received.

Each team will have 15 minutes to present an interim report of the internationalisation project to get feedback from the class and class facilitator before submitting the final report. This presentation will be followed by a 10-minute Q&A.

Participation: All members should participate (at least two presenters present the 15-minute presentation, and all members participate in Q&A. Members who don’t present should try their best to contribute to the Q&A.). Part A will be assessed individually on their contribution.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"d415c872dbbfd850eb6b147a3a9619af","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO8","cl_id":"d415c872dbbfd850eb6b147a3a9619b0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"d415c872dbbfd850eb6b147a3a9619b1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"dc15c872dbbfd850eb6b147a3a9619ae","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"dc15c872dbbfd850eb6b147a3a9619af","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"dc15c872dbbfd850eb6b147a3a9619b0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"dc15c872dbbfd850eb6b147a3a9619b1","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"70154c72dbbfd850eb6b147a3a961993","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 3: Individual course reflection","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"25","description":"

At the conclusion of the course, you are required to submit course reflections synthesising the lessons learned from the 12 Units.

Your reflection about how this course is relevant to your current profession and future business endeavours is only shared with the Class Facilitator.

Topics can include, but are not limited to:

1.    how this course has provided analytical frameworks for you to analyse the industry and business that you are engaged in

2.    an analysis of the business/industry of interest, with one or a few frameworks in the course

3.    how your understanding has changed at a personal level, if at all, as a consequence of this course

4.    identify a few critical next-steps that you might want to engage with in terms of professional development in a globalised world.
