Business School","assoc_class_translated":"Program","assoc_duration_hb_display":"","assoc_current_version":{},"links":[]}],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"MNGT6583 - International Business Experience","description":"

The forces of globalisation have increased the permeability of traditional boundaries around countries, economies and industries. These forces include the expansion of international trade and investment, the growth of multinational corporations (MNCs), and significant improvements in communication and transportation technologies. These technological and transportation advances have facilitated the appearance of a whole new set of international entrepreneurs who, taking advantage of the reduced distance across markets, have been extremely successful in spawning a new breed of born global ventures and initiatives. Being able to identify and capitalise on the opportunities arising from this new world order is something that cannot be learned without being exposed more intensely to the new global business environment.


However, these forces shrinking the 'distance' between countries have not emerged without controversy, and thus they have failed to transform our world into a fully integrated 'global village'. Tensions across ethnic, religious and linguistic divides, as well as other home-grown regulatory efforts protecting local interests, have counterbalanced these centripetal forces, creating a more complex, uncertain and competitive business environment than ever before. The resulting 'semi-globalised' world represents an environment in which socioeconomic and political boundaries have a central and enduring role in shaping the activities of MNCs and international entrepreneurs. This new reality also calls for a reassessment of what it means to be a manager within MNCs. Managers are now pressed to not only provide benefits from commonalities across markets, but to also embrace differences among them. It is this need to be aware and to fully comprehend these differences that requires a new type of MNC leader or entrepreneur: what is called a cosmopolitan leader.


This course offers one possible path towards the personal developmental processes AGSM students need to embrace in becoming cosmopolitan leaders. The course combines different in-class activities with experiential learning based on first-hand encounters with businesses environments that are culturally, physically and institutionally distant from the typical experiences of managers and entrepreneurs working in Australia. While the chosen locations (i.e. countries) may vary each time this course is delivered, the activities executed locally and in the countries visited remain aligned with the course aims described in the ensuing section.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"5dd1a97bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619a0","name":"Independent research - Intensive"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 1: Pre-departure work: Self-introduction","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"5","description":"

You will post  an informative self-intrudction to introduce yourself to the class. A sample introduction of the course facilitator will be provided in Moodle for your reference. Introduce yourself to the class not just as a business person or professional, but also as a ‘whole person’ with hobbies and personality, and leave an impression on others who have never met you until we get together in China.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"1dd1a97bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a96197b","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"3cd1a97bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a96194f","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 2: Team project presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"5","weighting":"15","description":"

You will work within a small team of classmates to investigate the local environment and analyse how environmental factors (e.g. economic and cultural) affect doing business in this country. For example, teams may be asked to go to a local fresh market and interview local residents about their daily consumption behaviours. The Course Facilitator will conduct a short session to prepare each team for their task in advance.

After on-site investigation, each team is required to develop and deliver a 10-minute presentation to the rest of the group synthesising the research they have performed assessing the particular market or social environment they have studied.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"1dd1a97bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a96197b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"45d1a97bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961973","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"81d1a97bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961976","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"cdd1a97bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961978","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"d5d1a97bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961997","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"74d1a97bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961954","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 3: Daily facilitation","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"6","weighting":"20","description":"

Student teams will act as ‘Lead facilitators’ for one to two days of the tour. Each team of facilitators is responsible for:

1.    conducting research about organisations that we are visiting during the days they are allocated and for forming meaningful questions for the class to consider before the visits

2.    conducting research about each speaker’s background and introducing the speaker to the class before their talk

3.    gift giving (AGSM will provide the gifts) – presenting gifts and thanking the speakers in a manner that is appropriate to the local culture.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"d5d1a97bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961997","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"74d1a97bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961965","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 4: Deep reflection exercise","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"7","weighting":"30","description":"

Following the field-study tour, you are required to submit the following, synthesising the lessons learned from the whole experience (Stage 1 plus Stage 2 activities):

Part A: an opinion piece (700 words) published in the Moodle forum that summarises the key insights you gained during the tour and generates online discussion.

Part B: a self-reflection piece (800 words) submitted in Moodle via Turnitin that discusses how this whole experience has changed your previous understanding and viewpoint. It should explicitly attend to whether, as a consequence of this whole experience, you feel more prepared to effectively work with people from a different cultural background from yourself. Finally, the report needs to identify a few critical next-steps that you might want to take in terms of professional development that are inspired by this tour.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"15d1a97bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a96199a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"51d1a97bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a96199d","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"8dd1a97bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961969","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 1: Participation: Face to face","assessment_type":{"label":"Attendance","value":"attendance"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"5","description":"

You are required to engage in all scheduled activities (Stages 1 and 2). Additionally, you are expected to actively and enthusiastically contribute in all discussions and exercises locally and during the field-study tour.

Much of the learning in this course comes from interaction between participants.

You need to demonstrate a good knowledge of the IB course materials, and make an effort to constructively facilitate dialogue between class members.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"1dd1a97bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a96197b","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"acd1a97bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961903","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 1: Pre departure work: Reading Reflection","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"15","description":"

You will publish a Reading Reflection of approximately 500 words in the Moodle forum that elaborates on your own ideas about a particular topic related to the course materials (including readings and videos) provided in Moodle. To express your view and also to stimulate others’ thoughts, an interesting and thought-provoking topic and engaging writing style are essential. Fellow students are encouraged to reply to this report and these replies will be evaluated in terms of their quantity and quality. This piece is expected to be 500 words, and maximum no more than 700 words.

When publishing your article in Moodle, please use the article title as the title of your thread. For examples of typical business articles by columnists, please see http://www.biznews.com/category/columnists/lucy-kellaway/. No referencing is needed.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"1dd1a97bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a96197b","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"f0d1a97bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a96194b","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 1: Participation: Online","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"10","description":"

Online participation, including commenting on each other’s pre-departure reports and post-tour Opinion Pieces.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"1dd1a97bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a96197b","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"f4d1a97bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961908","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/MNGT6583.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"MNGT7491 - Strategic Management 1","description":"Strategic Management 1: Detecting and Selecting Business Opportunities MNGT 7483
The Strategic Management Year (SM Year) is the capstone program of the MBA (Executive). The design of the SM Year is organised around the general manager's fundamental problems, and arranged to reflect the different stages of the organisational life cycle.
Detecting and Selecting Business Opportunities is the first of the four subjects in the SM Year.
The course is constructed around four specific problems faced by the manager in the early stages of a business:
  • How do I formulate a successful strategy?
  • How do I position the organisation to compete?
  • How do I sell a business plan to potential investors?
  • How do I evaluate the level of risks associated with a proposed business?

The course seeks to provide opportunity for you to explore the answers to these questions, and to develop self reflective team working and communication skills. Additionally the SM Year explores four themes across all four courses:
  • Economic Logic Formulation
  • Entrepreneurship
  • Leadership
  • Decision Making

contentlets.description:
Strategic Management 1: Detecting and Selecting Business Opportunities MNGT 7483 The Strategic Management Year (SM Year) is the capstone program of the MBA (Executive). The design of the SM Year is organised around the general manager's fundamental problems, and arranged to reflect the different stages of the organisational life cycle.
Detecting and Selecting Business Opportunities is the first of the four subjects in the SM Year.
The course is constructed around four specific problems faced by the manager in the early stages of a business:
  • How do I formulate a successful strategy?
  • How do I position the organisation to compete?
  • How do I sell a business plan to potential investors?
  • How do I evaluate the level of risks associated with a proposed business?
The course seeks to provide opportunity for you to explore the answers to these questions, and to develop self reflective team working and communication skills. Additionally the SM Year explores four themes across all four courses:
  • Economic Logic Formulation
  • Entrepreneurship
  • Leadership
  • Decision Making
contentlets.title: Strategic Management 1

The key questions that students will consider are: How do I detect and select business opportunities? How do I develop business opportunities? How do I grow a business? How do I transform a business? This course focuses on the second key question, i.e. how to develop business opportunities. Additionally, the SMY explores four themes across all four courses: Critical Thinking, Entrepreneurship, Leadership and Decision Making.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"MNGT7494 - Strategic Management 4","description":"

The Strategic Management Year (SMY) is the capstone course of the AGSM's EMBA. The design of the SMY course is organised around the general manager's fundamental problems, and arranged to reflect the different stages of the organisational life cycle. The course is divided into four stages:


Strategic Management 1: Detecting and Selecting Business Opportunities. The stage is constructed around four specific problems faced by the manager in the early stages of a business: How do I formulate a successful strategy? How do I position the organisation to compete? How do I sell a business plan to potential investors? How do I evaluate the level of risks associated with a proposed business? The stage seeks to provide opportunity for students to explore the answers to these questions, and to develop self reflective team working and communication skills


Strategic Management 2: Developing Business Opportunities. This stage focuses on the second key question, i.e. how to develop business opportunities. Students will learn about different organisational architectures and how to decide which architectures are most appropriate for different business opportunities. Students will consider organisational arrangements required to successfully implement strategies, as well as organisational arrangements required to generate new strategic alternatives. 


Strategic Management 3: Growing Business. The stage is constructed around four specific problems faced by the manager in the middle stages of a business: What options for growth do I have? How do I implement a growth option? How do I sell a growth plan to internal and external stakeholders? How do I evaluate and manage risks associated with a proposed growth option?


Strategic Management 4: Transforming Business. The fourth stage in the SMY addresses how a General Manager can respond to performance risks generated from a lack of external fit that might already exist or be likely to exist in the near future. The risk to external fit can come from any one of a number of sources: regulation, buyer power, technology, competitors, supplier power etc. When external fit is at risk it is likely that the business model will need to be reexamined and redefined, leading to transformational change. At the end of this stage, students will be able to: Recommend a transformation strategy for an organisation, Develop a plan for the implementation of transformational change, Evaluate and manage the risks associated with a proposed transformational change and Facilitate an organisation's ability to renew itself proactively through identifying and interpreting weak signals in both the external and internal environments.


Additionally, the SMY explores four themes across all four courses: Critical Thinking, Entrepreneurship, Leadership and Decision Making.

The Strategic Management Year (SMY) is the capstone course of the AGSM's EMBA. The design of the SMY course is organised around the general manager's fundamental problems, and arranged to reflect the different stages of the organisational life cycle. The course is divided into four stages:

Strategic Management 1: Detecting and Selecting Business Opportunities. The stage is constructed around four specific problems faced by the manager in the early stages of a business: How do I formulate a successful strategy? How do I position the organisation to compete? How do I sell a business plan to potential investors? How do I evaluate the level of risks associated with a proposed business? The stage seeks to provide opportunity for students to explore the answers to these questions, and to develop self reflective team working and communication skills

Strategic Management 2: Developing Business Opportunities. This stage focuses on the second key question, i.e. how to develop business opportunities. Students will learn about different organisational architectures and how to decide which architectures are most appropriate for different business opportunities. Students will consider organisational arrangements required to successfully implement strategies, as well as organisational arrangements required to generate new strategic alternatives. 

Strategic Management 3: Growing Business. The stage is constructed around four specific problems faced by the manager in the middle stages of a business: What options for growth do I have? How do I implement a growth option? How do I sell a growth plan to internal and external stakeholders? How do I evaluate and manage risks associated with a proposed growth option?

Strategic Management 4: Transforming Business. The fourth stage in the SMY addresses how a General Manager can respond to performance risks generated from a lack of external fit that might already exist or be likely to exist in the near future. The risk to external fit can come from any one of a number of sources: regulation, buyer power, technology, competitors, supplier power etc. When external fit is at risk it is likely that the business model will need to be reexamined and redefined, leading to transformational change. At the end of this stage, students will be able to: Recommend a transformation strategy for an organisation, Develop a plan for the implementation of transformational change, Evaluate and manage the risks associated with a proposed transformational change and Facilitate an organisation's ability to renew itself proactively through identifying and interpreting weak signals in both the external and internal environments.

Additionally, the SMY explores four themes across all four courses: Critical Thinking, Entrepreneurship, Leadership and Decision Making.

Strategic Leadership","description":"

This course explores the complexity of strategic leadership and will give you tools and a mindset to effectively work in the challenging and rewarding environment in which senior executives lead. As you progress in your career, the requirements of operating at a higher level involve taking multiple perspectives, seeing the big picture, balancing long-term with short-term objectives, working with a diverse range of stakeholders, implementing strategies using informal influence as well as authority, and making strategic choices that involve trade-offs and risk, to name but a few.


Strategic choices are best made by formulating a clear and coherent strategy based on an evaluation of the operating environment. How can we create and capture value for the organisation and its key stakeholders given competitive, regulatory, technological and global forces, and the resources we have available? Where will we play and where will we not play?


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"applies_to_all","name":"Assessments"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 1: Participation","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

Participation in online activities, discussions, quizzes and web conference.

Online discussion

The online discussion component is designed to help you engage with the course material throughout the entire term. As you complete readings and activities, you will identify questions and insights that we ask you to share in online discussion forums. Anything that puzzles you, or that you find particularly useful, something that raises questions or provides you with long-sought answers, or aspects that trigger a particular reaction in you, can be shared online. Classmates will join in your discussion and in that way, help you, and others, process the information in the course materials. You can comment on and contribute to discussion threads initiated by others. 

To encourage dialogue, contributions to online discussion forums should be no longer than 200 words per post. Please make sure your comments are substantive (rather than a short ‘I agree’ or ‘disagree’) and that you approach the discussion with informed opinions based on unit materials. While it is acceptable and expected that you have your own opinion, please show respect toward others in expressing this opinion.

Quizzes and web conference

This assessment also requires you to participate in two self-diagnostic multiple-choice quizzes which are designed for you to test your knowledge of the course materials. The first quiz needs to be completed before the residential, the second quiz by the end of Week 9. You need to score a minimum of 60% on each quiz in order to complete the activity.

You will also participate in a web conference with your team and course facilitator.

  • Step 1: My Leadership Story due on Thursday (Week 3) by 3pm Sydney time - 3 minutes maximum
  • Step 2: Peer Feedback due on Thursday (Week 5) by 3pm Sydney time
  • Step 3: My Pitch due on Thursday (Week 6) by 3pm Sydney time - 3 minutes maximum
  • Step 4: Peer assessment due on Thursday (Week 7) by 3pm Sydney time

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"f3c87394dbf75450eb6b147a3a961975","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO8","cl_id":"f3c87394dbf75450eb6b147a3a961976","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"f3c87394dbf75450eb6b147a3a961977","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"fbc87394dbf75450eb6b147a3a961974","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"fbc87394dbf75450eb6b147a3a961977","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"08d8b394dbf75450eb6b147a3a96196a","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 3: Strategy analysis (team)","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

For this assignment, you need to select one of the strategic leader interviews completed by your team. The selection should be based on which organisation is of most interest to your team, and which will allow you good access to relevant data to complete the strategy analysis. Your team will analyse the strategy of this organisation in order to identify recommendations for improved performance.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"f3c87394dbf75450eb6b147a3a961978","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"fbc87394dbf75450eb6b147a3a961975","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"fbc87394dbf75450eb6b147a3a961976","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"7fc8b394dbf75450eb6b147a3a961939","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 4: Strategic leadership development plan","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"35","description":"

This assignment helps you answer the question: What do I need to do to successfully transition into my next/first strategic leadership role? To do this, you will develop an action plan. A comprehensive action plan has many parts that help clarify what you plan to achieve, why and how. It identifies sources of support and any obstacles you might face. To help you craft this development plan, draw on the Unit on Leadership Development Plans (Unit 10) in the course materials.

This course is built around the observation that creativity and innovativeness can be developed and that they can be managed to yield consistently successful outcomes. It takes the stance that just as total quality management (TQM) approaches took the randomness out of manufacturing to yield consistent quality, an appropriately developed innovation process can take the randomness and chaos out of innovation management.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"applies_to_all","name":"Assessments"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 1B: Team Paper","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

In this assignment, your team will be able to apply learnings from pre-residential units and residential workshop activities demonstrating that you have applied the design thinking methodology and presented an innovative solution to the problem presented to you in the residential.

The goal is to be creative, but also to ensure that the solution is valuable to users.

Make sure you identify and clearly articulate a concrete client/audience for your report.

In the appendix, you present the data that you generated in the various stages in the design thinking process. However, the reader should not be required to read the appendix to be convinced that you are a design thinking expert.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"4c2e4d77dbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619d2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO10","cl_id":"502e4d77dbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619de","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"842e4d77dbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619ca","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"882e4d77dbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619d5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO11","cl_id":"9c2e4d77dbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619e0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"bf1e4d77dbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619ab","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"c02e4d77dbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619cd","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO8","cl_id":"d42e4d77dbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619d8","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"671e4d77dbb91c50eb6b147a3a96197f","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 2 Step 2: Updated Project Plan","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"","description":"

In this step, document the progress you made by composing an update of your initial project plan. You will submit this in Moodle. A link is provided in the ‘Assessments’ section, which will take you to the ‘Workshop’ interface.

Your peers will evaluate the quality of the updated plan and give you feedback by the end of Week 7. (Similarly, you will give feedback on your peers’ papers by going back to the assignment link and evaluating the students who have been assigned to you for feedback.)

This document should consist of three components. Firstly, details of the three groups that matter in your project (see below); next, a framework and related initial observations regarding the user group; and finally, a customer journey map.

The three groups that matter:

  • The audience

Who are you writing the report for? Examples could be your direct boss,
the leadership of the company, potential investors in your start-up, etc.

  • The design thinking project team

Who in your organisation is taking part in the design thinking process?

  • The users

Who will directly use or benefit from the innovation you are designing?
This last group comprises the people who you will study and observe.

Note: Part of the post-residential participation.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO9","cl_id":"142e4d77dbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619db","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"4c2e4d77dbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619d2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO10","cl_id":"502e4d77dbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619de","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"842e4d77dbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619ca","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"882e4d77dbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619d5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO11","cl_id":"9c2e4d77dbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619e0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"bf1e4d77dbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619ab","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"c02e4d77dbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619cd","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"c82e4d77dbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619ae","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO8","cl_id":"d42e4d77dbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619d8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO12","cl_id":"d82e4d77dbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619e3","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"671e4d77dbb91c50eb6b147a3a961988","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 2 Step 3: Full paper","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"5","weighting":"50","description":"

The most important written output of your innovation project is a full paper on your innovation proposal. This paper will demonstrate that you have applied the design thinking methodology in creating an innovation for your organisation or your start-up and will present an innovation solution that will allow your organisation or start-up to create and capture value.

Make sure that you have clearly identified and carefully articulated a concrete client/audience for your report.

In the appendix, you present the data that you generated in the various stages in the design thinking process. However, the reader should not be required to read the appendix to be convinced that you are a design thinking expert.

Note that you are asked to do very similar things in both the team and individual papers on purpose. In both papers you need to persuade a reader of two things:

  1. that the proposed solution is a desirable one for the user
  2. that you are a truly competent design thinking practitioner (they are sceptical of your skills and hence you need to show them).
","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO9","cl_id":"142e4d77dbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619db","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"4c2e4d77dbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619d2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO10","cl_id":"502e4d77dbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619de","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"842e4d77dbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619ca","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"882e4d77dbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619d5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO11","cl_id":"9c2e4d77dbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619e0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"bf1e4d77dbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619ab","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"c02e4d77dbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619cd","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"c82e4d77dbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619ae","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO8","cl_id":"d42e4d77dbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619d8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO12","cl_id":"d82e4d77dbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619e3","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"671e4d77dbb91c50eb6b147a3a961999","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 2 Step 1: Initial Project Plan","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"","description":"

The purpose of this assignment step is to get you started in planning your individual project for the course. The assignment has two components. You are asked to describe a series of possible problems in your organisation that could benefit from an innovative solution. The design thinking methodology for creating innovation solutions with various stakeholders requires you to carefully plan meetings and workshops. For this reason, you will lay out a tentative project with milestones and deliverables from Week 3 to Week 10 of the course. This first draft project plan will be discussed during the residential in Week 4.

Note: Part of the pre-residential participation.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO9","cl_id":"142e4d77dbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619db","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"4c2e4d77dbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619d2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO10","cl_id":"502e4d77dbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619de","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"842e4d77dbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619ca","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"882e4d77dbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619d5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO11","cl_id":"9c2e4d77dbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619e0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"bf1e4d77dbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619ab","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"c02e4d77dbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619cd","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"c82e4d77dbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619ae","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO8","cl_id":"d42e4d77dbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619d8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO12","cl_id":"d82e4d77dbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619e3","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"6f1e4d77dbb91c50eb6b147a3a961983","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 1A: Team presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"4","description":"

During the residential, your team will be presented with a problem that allows you to practise the design thinking methodology around which the course is based. You will work on this problem in teams, during and after the residential.

On the final day of the residential, each team will present their initial ideas about the solution. The presentation will mimic the structure of the full paper that your team will complete after the residential.

Your class peers will evaluate your team presentation using the given criteria and marking rubric. Students will recieve an individual mark.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"4c2e4d77dbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619d2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO10","cl_id":"502e4d77dbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619de","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"842e4d77dbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619ca","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"882e4d77dbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619d5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO11","cl_id":"9c2e4d77dbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619e0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"bf1e4d77dbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619ab","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"c02e4d77dbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619cd","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO8","cl_id":"d42e4d77dbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619d8","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"9f1e4d77dbb91c50eb6b147a3a961961","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 3A: Pre-residential participation","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"6","weighting":"8","description":"

The purpose of the following activities is to help you develop your ideas formatively through individual work (reflections and quizzes) while taking part in learning activities with your peers. For this reason, the assessment criteria evaluate your level of participation. You will be awarded 8% towards your final mark if you have completed all of the following tasks:

  • two reading reflections on readings of your choosing, each of 100 words minimum, posted to the Moodle discussion forum (Weeks 1 to 3)
  • four of the unit activities (two required ones, Activity 1.1 and 3.1, and two of your choosing) in the Moodle discussion forum (Weeks 1 to 3)
  • four reactions to reading reflections of other students in the Moodle discussion forum (Weeks 1 to 3)
  • two self-diagnostic multiple-choice quizzes in Moodle (Weeks 2 and 3).
","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"4c2e4d77dbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619d2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO10","cl_id":"502e4d77dbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619de","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"842e4d77dbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619ca","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"882e4d77dbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619d5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO11","cl_id":"9c2e4d77dbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619e0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"bf1e4d77dbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619ab","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"c02e4d77dbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619cd","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO8","cl_id":"d42e4d77dbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619d8","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"af1e4d77dbb91c50eb6b147a3a96199d","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 3B: Residential and post-residential participation","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"7","weighting":"8","description":"

The quality of the residential depends on students having completed the units and engaged with other course resources, and being able to apply the concepts to new problems. The Class Facilitator will evaluate your contribution to class discussion based primarily on the quality of the contribution rather than the quantity.

After the residential, you are required to give feedback two times to peers as follows:

  • evaluation of contributions of team members for Assignment 1 in Week 6
  • feedback to peers on Assignment 2 Step 2 in Week 7 by Saturday at 3pm.

contentlets.description: This course is built around the observation that creativity and innovativeness can be developed and that they can be managed to yield consistently successful outcomes. It takes the stance that just as total quality management (TQM) approaches took the randomness out of manufacturing to yield consistent quality, an appropriately developed innovation process can take the randomness and chaos out of innovation management.
contentlets.title: Innovation

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"MNGT7497","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"12 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"MNGT7497 - Growth","description":"

Congratulations on successfully completing the first half of the Executive Agenda Year!


The aim of MNGT7497 Growth is for you to develop strategic thinking and analysis skills that you will apply in formulating effective growth strategies for your organisation. You will gain these skills through engaging in activities and assessments that help you develop in the areas of identifying, evaluating and planning the implementation of value-creating growth options. We will draw on your experiences, written case studies, published articles, book chapters, videos, podcasts, a live case study and simulations to help build your skills in these areas.


You will analyse a range of different growth options available to managers. Two primary paths for organisational growth involve: (a) expanding into new products/services and (b) expanding into new markets (i.e. geographic locations and customer segments).


Another important dimension to consider, together with the two primary paths, is resources. Organisations can be viewed as bundles of resources. Examples of resources are brand names, in-house knowledge of technology, skilled personnel, trade contracts, machinery, capital, efficient procedures, etc. As we will explore in the course, analysing the organisation from the resource perspective can help to identify new strategic growth options. Note that our use of the term 'Resources' includes capabilities and management systems.


Also, for each of the two expansion paths, there are several alternative vehicles for growth. An organisation can elect to grow organically by expanding the market share of its current business, innovating into new products/services, or opening greenfield sites in new geographic locations. Alternatively, an organisation may decide to grow through merger or acquisition. Finally, strategic partnerships or alliances represent yet another vehicle for growth arranged through long-term contracts/licences, equity stakes or joint ventures (JVs) between separate organisations. Many organisations employ all of these vehicles in their growth strategies.


In the course, we will discuss each of these paths and vehicles for growing organisations and evaluate options for growth in a variety of sectors and contexts. However, identifying attractive growth options does not automatically translate into success. Managers also need to successfully implement a growth strategy to make it work. An integrated growth strategy includes a plan for obtaining the capabilities needed to succeed in each growth option, the timing and phasing of each step involved to expand the organisation, and aligning the structure and systems for managing organisational growth.


A very important aspect of implementing an effective growth strategy entails identifying and thinking through the risks involved. There are substantial risks associated with growth strategies. A great deal of research shows that the expected economic benefits of diversifying into new products/services are often not captured, and that many mergers and acquisitions are failures. Similarly, international expansion often falls short of delivering the expected returns. However, this has not stopped managers from engaging in widespread diversification, implementing mergers and acquisitions, or expanding internationally in attmpts to fuel company growth.


Most of the medium and large Australian companies we read about in the business press every day have expanded beyond a single product or single market, and many have been involved in a merger or acquisition. In the course we will discuss how to limit risk by identifying growth options that leverage the existing strengths of the organisation, how to evaluate whether an organisation is the natural or best owner of a given business, and how to avoid paying too much for an acquisition.

During the four-day residential, you will start developing a growth strategy for a real organisation. Early in the residential, a senior manager from the organisation will introduce and set up the live case study for us as a guest speaker. By the end of the residential, your team will present a recommended growth strategy for the organisation to achieve its growth objectives. The senior manager from the organisation will provide comments and suggestions during the presentations.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"25c1297bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961935","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"39c1297bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961940","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"61c1297bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961938","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO8","cl_id":"75c1297bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961943","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"a9c1297bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a96192f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"e5c1297bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961932","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"e9c1297bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a96193d","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"09c1297bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961907","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 1: Quiz A","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"5","description":"

The first assessment is composed of three small quizzes that act as an active learning tool to promote better recall and deeper learning. These are also used as a Readiness Assurance Test to assess your mastery of the course material prior to the four-day residential session.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"e5c1297bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961932","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"4dc1e57bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619f9","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 3: Individual Growth Strategy Paper","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"5","weighting":"35","description":"

In this assessment, you are expected to formulate a recommended growth strategy for your own organisation or any other organisation you might have extensive knowledge about or ready access to information about. The recommended growth strategy must be different from any strategy or components of a strategy that you submitted for EAY1 or EAY2. This assessment is another opportunity to apply the concepts and lessons learned in the course to a real-world organisation, and is the same format and structure as the Live case growth strategy paper.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"25c1297bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961935","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"39c1297bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961940","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"61c1297bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961938","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO8","cl_id":"75c1297bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961943","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"a9c1297bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a96192f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"e5c1297bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961932","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"e9c1297bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a96193d","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"51c1297bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a96190c","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 4A : Participation during the four-day residential","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"6","weighting":"5","description":"

The four-day residential component of the course is designed to help students practise applying course concepts and tools so that they will be able to transfer course knowledge and skills beyond the classroom to real-world problems after the course is over. In order to accomplish this goal, the interpretations and varied experiences of every student participating in the residential sessions are critical. As students work on residential activities, they are encouraged to identify questions and insights that they can raise when those topics are brought to bear during the residential discussion sessions. Anything that puzzles students, or that they find particularly useful, or something that raises questions, might trigger particularly insightful discussions or revelations in other students. That is why openly asking questions and sharing with the rest of the class specific experiences make the residential sessions particularly (arguably uniquely) useful for all participants.

Details

Students should aim to make substantive contributions (informed by the course materials or by their professional or personal experiences) to raise the quality and depth of class discussions. While it is acceptable and expected that each student would have their own opinion, we expect all students to show respect towards others. The class facilitator will assess students’ contributions throughout the whole residential based primarily on the quality of these contributions rather than their quantity.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"a9c1297bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a96192f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"e5c1297bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961932","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"51c1297bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a96191d","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 1: Quiz B","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"5","description":"

The first assessment is composed of three small quizzes that act as an active learning tool to promote better recall and deeper learning. These are also used as a Readiness Assurance Test to assess your mastery of the course material prior to the four-day residential session.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"e5c1297bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961932","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"85c1e57bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619fe","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 4B : Participation in post-residential simulation","assessment_type":{"label":"Lab work","value":"lab_work"},"assessment_id":"7","weighting":"5","description":"

Mergers and acquisitions are a key vehicle for implementing new growth options. Evidence from research shows that appropriately managing the integration process in the post-merger or post-acquisition stage is perhaps the most challenging aspect of any M&A. In order to gain experience with the integration process, students will engage in an online simulation of a merger between two retail banks. Unit 9 provides instructions for preparing for and playing the simulation

Details

Completing this assessment will require students to:

  1. individually complete the online simulation by Friday of Week 7. The simulation takes a little under two hours (if you do not stop the simulation).
  2. watch the debriefing video posted in Moodle by the Course Coordinator
  3. post short contribution(s) (200 words) to the Moodle course discussion synthesising the key lessons you learned from the simulation and any insights you can use in your own organisation. This discussion post is due in Week 7 by 11am Friday Sydney time.
","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"a9c1297bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a96192f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"e5c1297bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961932","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"99c1297bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961921","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 1: Quiz C","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"5","description":"

The first assessment is composed of three small quizzes that act as an active learning tool to promote better recall and deeper learning. These are also used as a Readiness Assurance Test to assess your mastery of the course material prior to the four-day residential session.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"e5c1297bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961932","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"cdc1297bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961902","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 4C : Team participation","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"8","weighting":"10","description":"

Multiple activities during this course are performed through an active collaboration of a team of students. The expectation at the level of the MBA (Executive) program is that students are proactively engaged and consistently collaborate and even help overcome any challenges their team might face when trying to accomplish a particular objective. In other words, self-awareness, proactivity and leadership when engaging in teamwork are expected from students. In order to reward those students who consistently meet these expectations during each and every one of the team-based activities in this course, the teammates of each of the students participating in this course will have the opportunity to assess whether each of their team members has met these expectations.

Details

By the start of Week 9, you will receive a link to complete the online peer assessment survey for each member of your team. When completing the online peer assessment, please add in at least a brief comment for each team member on all three questions to justify your rating. Your ratings and comments for each team member will be anonymous, but will be shared with them (along with the ratings and comments from every other team member). Do NOT select the Not Applicable check box for any of the questions; they are all applicable! If you do not complete the online peer assessment, then your ratings on all three questions for all of your team members will be counted as zero and this will negatively impact your team members’ participation mark. Be sure to scroll down and answer all three questions on the online assessment; if you do not scroll down to the bottom you may miss the third question and the default ratings are zero (which will negatively impact your team members’ mark).

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"a9c1297bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a96192f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"e5c1297bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961932","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"d1c1297bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961926","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/MNGT7497.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"MNGT7498","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"12 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"MNGT7498 - Transformation","description":"

Transformation means dealing with the challenges of change and uncertainty, sensing, seizing and transforming. This requires critical thinking to deal with the frequent paradoxical choices in todays business environment where transformation is increasingly an ongoing activity rather than a once-in-a-career event. In this course students learn to accept and embrace uncertainty. You will build important skills and mindsets to lead organisational business model shifts and organisational transformation projects with confidence.


In a world besotted with disruption, globalisation and the digital economy, the concepts contained in MNGT7498 Transformation are of paramount importance to any leader looking to run a successful organisation over the next decade (and beyond). This course also provides an opportunity to re-calibrate your personal and professional transformation journey refining your path to success as you exit the program.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"applies_to_all","name":"Assessments"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 1: Team Case Analysis and Presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

As a group, your team will present an analysis and recommendation for an organisation during Day 4 of the Residential. This presentation will include an analysis of the current situation, a proposal for a new business model, and a recommended transformation strategy – supported by financial analysis.

Your team will self-select an organisation to investigate. However, to enhance cohort learning, the Class Facilitator will request that the teams select different organisations.

The preferred type of organisation to investigate is one that is experiencing serious performance deterioration or one that may wish to be proactive in anticipation of expected negative trends. In either case, the organisation will need to redesign its business model to meet current and future challenges. An alternative, with Class Facilitator approval, is to examine an organisation that needed a transformation but failed to implement one. What should they have done?

Importantly, in either approach you need to have access to top-level people in the organisation and to information on the organisation (see detail below).

The investigation will be similar to a consulting project where your team will be able to provide the results of your investigation to the participating organisation (this is a key benefit for them).

As a group, your team presented an analysis and recommendation for an organisation during the Residential. This presentation included an analysis of the current situation, a proposal for a new business model and a recommended transformation strategy.

In Assignment 2, as an individual, you are required to complete an evaluation of your peers’ teamwork. This assignment is compulsory.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"412e8d77dbb91c50eb6b147a3a961945","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO8","cl_id":"592e8d77dbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619a0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO9","cl_id":"952e8d77dbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619a3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"cd2e8d77dbb91c50eb6b147a3a96199a","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"342e8d77dbb91c50eb6b147a3a961923","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 3: Transformation Project Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"45","description":"

There is a large amount of evidence that practising a newly learned skill is beneficial in both embedding and further developing knowledge. Thus, Assignment 3 is designed to allow practise in organisational transformation. The intent is for you to demonstrate that you can apply organisational transformation tools and frameworks to accomplish a transformation that is important, strategic or beyond your normal work requirements.

It is highly recommended that you begin planning for this assignment as early as possible! Transformation projects can frequently take weeks, months and sometimes years. Stronger assignments will capture more steps in the process.

You may create a new project in your organisation or team, you may create a new project in a social group, you may select a project in your organisation where you are a key player, or you may discuss other options with your Class Facilitator.

While our readings explore top-level organisational change, the tools and frameworks can be applied at any level, so you may select a project appropriate for your level in the organisation. In the rare case where you cannot create or find a transformation project, you may be allowed to: 1) assess a previous change process, or 2) analyse a situation where you were subject to a transformation and you can then explain how you responded to get things done (please discuss with your Class Facilitator). However, please note that these alternatives risk receiving a lower mark for the ‘demonstrate doing’ aspect of the assignment.

We have several readings about organisational transformation that will create the foundations for this assignment. Specifically, we expect the use of Kotter’s eight steps (either version) and tools to support each step from the other readings. These additional tools (also see Residential slides) will enable you to ensure that your recommendations are justified. Please see Units 3 and 4.

The activities that will be assessed for participation are as follows.

Checkpoint Conference Calls, Peer Evaluations and Discussion Forums during the 10-week session (excluding the Residential days) 10%:

You are required to submit team checkpoint reports, attend checkpoint conference calls and participate in discussion forums (major portion of the mark). This participation activity will be evaluated based on quality (not only quantity) of your contribution. See assessment criteria below.

Residential Participation 10%:

You will have the opportunity to actively participate in discussion during the Residential. Participation in such activity will be evaluated based on quality (not only quantity) of your contribution. See assessment criteria below.

You are also required to peer-assess the team case presentations.
